dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a CANDLE, its base ringed by dripped wax. It’s perched on the sill of a small window, bathed in grayish, early morning light. A SNUFFER enters the frame and extinguishes the flame. We PULL BACK to see the MAIDSERVANT who has just put out candle, moving onto the next candle in the long corridor, snuffing it out as well. And onto the next when she HEARS The ECHO of footfalls and clanking swords. As THREE MEN r the corner she steps back, head bowed, making room for th Walking briskly toward us are THOMAS ANDREWS (Sheriff of Northamptonshire) flanked by two Earls - SHREWSBURY and K They pass by the Maidservant without acknowledging her. S watches them go as they round another corner. Andrews and his men arrive at a small door. A GUARD await them. Upon their arrival the Guard fetches a set of keys his belt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing - a foreboding, turreted castle rising from marshland of an adjacent river, surrounded by a moat. We the UNLOCKING OF A BOLT as we CUT TO--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY STUART - Queen of Scots, Dowager Queen of France. But we see her from BEHIND - her back to us. And this is where we shall stay for now. Seeing events as she does, following from just a few feet to the rear. She is on her knees in prayer, joined by her CHAMBERMAIDS an OLDER MARY SETON (the younger version of whom we shall introduce soon), facing a small window which overlooks th landscape we just saw. As the heavy door pivots open, revealing Andrews, she remains in prayer, her back to him He bows his head, then, with solemnity and respect--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREWS
dialogues.text: It’s time. Mary stands, as do her Servants. She’s wearing a long, bl satin gown. A white cap and laced veil against which her dark, auburn hair is lustrous. It’s her hair that we’re d to - since we’ve yet to see her face. She goes to a side table and retrieves two carefully cho items, an ivory crucifix in one hand, a Latin prayer book the other. Meanwhile one of the Maidservants loops a string of rosar beads with a golden cross to a girdle at her waist. Anoth fastens a gold chain around her neck, from which hangs a medallion bearing the image of Christ as the Lamb of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind. Mary is being led across by the Earls and Guards. She pauses to look up at the sky. The last time s will feel the sun directly on her face.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREWS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your grace. She resumes following her escort, who have paused for her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUEEN ELIZABETH - from behind - walking alone, slowly, as in a daze. She looks up at the sky, then lowers her head. begins to sob. We can’t see her tears, but we can see her body shaking.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your grace. We shift focus to WILLIAM CECIL on the far side of the courtyard. He is her most trusted advisor on the Privy Council - a persuasive, manipulative man who understands realpolitik of power and wields it well. From behind him, see Elizabeth quickly dry her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re above and behind as Mary strides through a large se doors, her Ladies, Andrews and Guards in tow. Down the hall a little SERVANT GIRL peeks around the corn to get a glimpse. The MAIDSERVANT from the first scene gr her by the wrist and pulls her out of view. Mary rounds the corner, taking us to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast room filled with a hundred SPECTATORS. At the far of the room is a WOODEN STAGE. The crowd parts. She heads directly for the stage, mounts steps to the platform where two MEN stand waiting for her  Still behind her, from over her shoulder, we can see the crowd staring up, a hundred solemn faces - the KNIGHTS an GENTLEMEN OF NORTHAMPTONSHIRE. There is a low murmuring a number of men speak in hushed tones to each other. It’s worth noting that this crowd is ALL MEN. The only wo in attendance are Old Seton and Mary’s two Ladies. Mary’s back and the POV beyond fills the frame, but off- screen we hear three KNOCKS of a cane on the wooden platf to call the room to attention. A slight, barely noticeabl flinch from each knock as the room silences. The Clerk of Elizabeth's Privy Council, ROBERT BEALE - re aloud off-screen. We only hear his voice--

dialogues.speaker: BEALE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: By order of our sovereign Elizabeth, Queen of England, Wales and Ireland, Overlord of Scotland, certified by her Privy Council and Parliament, Mary Stuart is condemned to death this day, the eighth of February, the year of our Lord one thousand five hundred eighty-seven... During which we CUT from face to face of Nobles in the audience, all staring up at Mary in morbid fascination an anxiousness. We are in Mary’s POV now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Elizabeth’s back as a Guard opens the chamber door. Th COUNCIL stands and bows as she takes her seat. With a sli gesture she instructs them to sit. Cecil steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: For your fellow Princes on the continent - that they might know... He places a letter before her. She glances over it. An ATTENDANT brings her a quill and ink. She looks back up.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We will not ask God’s forgiveness for that which is just.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are still behind Mary. She stands. Two Earls remove he outer garment - the black satin - revealing a crimson gar beneath. The colour of martyrdom. A collective gasp. We CUT TO Noblemen in the midst of the crowd, gazing at h with disgust. One whispers to the other--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks herself a martyr.

dialogues.speaker: KNIGHTLEY
dialogues.text: Wretched woman. BACK TO Mary. She turns to the Executioner - BULL. We rem on her back. Bull bows his head in supplication--

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: I plead your forgiveness.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I forgive you with all my heart. You shall make an end of all my troubles. Bull gestures to a cushion before her in front of the blo As Mary kneels down she begins to recite a psalm in Latin

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Salve, Regina, Mater misericordie, vita, dulcedo, et spes nostra, salve. Ad te clamamus exsules filii Heve, In te Domino confido... As she repeats the prayer the camera COMES AROUND to face Mary for the FIRST TIME. As we do, we hear a SURGE of surf on a shore, and once we land upon her face, we are no longer in Fotheringhay Castle... It is 27 YEARS PRIOR and we are at--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary kneeling on the sand in prayer. The water is surging soaking her dress. She shivers from the cold but continue her prayer. The moment has the same solemnity as the execution sequen but the daylight and anticipation and Mary’s youth also charge it with the excitement and danger of a new beginni As the surf retreats she leans down and kisses the sand - first time she’s touched Scottish soil since she was a gi Behind her we can see her ship anchored in the distance. Several rowboats have been pulled up onto the shore - tru and other goods being unloaded by sailors. A distressed look on Mary’s ashen face while she’s still down, her face inches above the sand. She retches. Four w quickly come to her aid.  They are the “Four Marys” - BEATON, SETON, FLEMING and LIVINGSTON - Mary’s ladies-in-waiting and closest friends hear concerned chatter among them as they attend to their mistress.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: C’est fini. (It’s passed.) --which silences them. Mary cups her hand in the salt wat and brings it up to her mouth to wash her face clean. Set hands her a handkerchief. Mary dries her face then stands Horses are making their way onto the shore. On BOTHWELL - Scottish Lord and the Queen’s Champion. He has the harden bearing of a soldier accented by the flash of an adventur He looks down the shore and sees figures in the distance PEASANTS cockle-picking. Near them is a small wagon with Clydesdale pony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're further down the shore with the PEASANT FAMILY now: They include an OLDER MAN, TWO TEENAGE SONS and a LITTLE - his daughter. Bothwell is paying the OLDER MAN several coins as GUARDS emptying the wagon of cockles, dumping them on a pile in sand. Mary is nearby on foot beside her horse. Mary looks at the old Peasant. A hard, poor life is evide by the deep wrinkles in his face, a mouth turned inward b lost teeth. Then she looks to his DAUGHTER - in a dirty muddy burlap frock - who does not bow. She’s only five years old, the age Mary was when she fled to France. CUT TO the Nobleman helping the Four Marys into the peasa wagon. Livingston holds a handkerchief to her nose, put o by the fishy smell. The other three seem no less disguste BACK TO Mary as Bothwell helps her onto her horse. Legs astride, not side saddle. Once atop, she looks regal. Bothwell mounts his horse and leads the small entourage forward. The little girl runs to keep up with it. Her father yells to her but she ignores him, running alongside Mary’s hors Mary and the little girl lock eyes. She sees a curious an defiant fire in the girl’s expression which aligns with h own curious and defiant flame. Mary smiles at the girl. She smiles back, then stops. Mar turns her eyes forward again, as if staring into her futu  Bothwell turns to her, in French--

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Tout cela correspond a4 vos souvenirs? (Is it how you remember it?)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Je m’en souviens a4 peine. (I scarcely remember it at all.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In stark contrast to the rawness of the Scottish countrys we're in an opulent, formal chamber. RANDOLPH - the Engli Ambassador to Scotland - stands before Elizabeth. Cecil i off to her side. Dudley is to the other side, along with other LORDS. Elizabeth’s ladies sit on stools and pillows near her feet.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Her protector is Lord Bothwell, an able soldier.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: So she comes readied for war.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: She may well depart once married. But I cannot profess to know her purpose.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What says her brother?

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Moray is only her half-brother, Madam. I believe his allegiance is fully with us.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What proof?

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: He pledges to protect the Church of Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: And yet he has no power to make such a pledge if he is no longer Regent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nobles respect him.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: But can he control her?

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: (directed at Cecil) If she is like our Queen, she does not yield to a bridle. Giggles from the Ladies. Even Elizabeth is amused.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: So says our Master of the Horse. More giggles from the ladies. Cecil doubles down--

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Dudley) By bridle do you speak of mounts...? Dudley stiffens. This is a touchy subject to bring up ina public setting, but Cecil will not allow himself to be challenged by an inferior Lord. Then triples down--

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .»..or do you speak of matrimony? Elizabeth holds up her hand to silence everyone. Cecil ha gone far enough. He gives her a slight nod. She waits a b for solemnity to return, then--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Randolph) You may tell Scotland that we wish to love the Stuarts as our kin, but they should love us in return.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Madam - if I may speak... All eyes on Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: While she is on this island, she must bow to you, not to Rome. Our Catholics must know that a papist will never again sit on the English throne.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: She has offered to recognise my rightful claim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you make her heir. We owe her no such consolation.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What would you suggest?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (to Randolph) Is it fair to say that Moray would rather remain Regent?

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: His discomfort would imply so.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (back to Elizabeth) Let his discomfort feed hers. Kill her hope. And hopeless she may return to the comfort of the continent. Cecil switches tones.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course, if you should offer love, perhaps your love will sway her. But I do not know what mortal would choose a Prince’s love over a Prince’s crown. It’s enough to convince her. She turns to Randolph--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Speak to her brother. Make our demands clear.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Recognition without recompense.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: However you choose to convey it.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Aye, Madam - I shall go at once. During which Cecil shoots Dudley a look. This is how you bridle a Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on the EARL OF MORAY, Regent of Scotland and Mary’s half-brother. He is atop a small bridge with windows on either side as he watches Mary’s entourage approach benea The castle itself looms above them all. We can see a flurry of activity in the courtyard beyond SERVANTS darting through the courtyard in preparation for Queen’s arrival, hurriedly lighting torches. On his face see tenseness. He’d rather none of this were happening. Moray leaves the window to go and greet his sister. TIME CUT to the Courtyard. TIGHT on Mary’s outstretched h Then Moray’s face enters the frame and lightly kisses it. We PULL BACK to see Moray kneeling before her, removing h sword as he does so.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mon frére... (My brother) He stands and she embraces him. Bothwell watches from sev yards away. He and Moray lock eyes - mutual distrust - as Moray and Mary embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Moray and the Four Marys make their way through corridors and a series of chambers, some half-furnished a being decorated for the Queen, others still bare. Everyth feels a bit ad hoc and rushed. The servants bow as Mary passes. She soaks it in during the following exchange wit Moray - only vaguely familiar. On the whole she might as be laying eyes upon these rooms for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: You must be tired.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I am quite well.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Supper is being prepared. We can have it brought to your chamber if you like.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you. A beat. Moray considers his next question, then asks it casually, though it’s far from a casual question--

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: How long will you be staying?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: At Holyrood?

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: In Scotland.  10. She answers him just as casually, though like the questio itself, there’s nothing casual about it’s substance.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Are you already planning my departure?

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Of course not. We’ve long awaited your return. Moray turns to a servant - KATE, elderly - who has been trailing behind them. MORAY (CONT’D) Kate will show you to your chambers.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: This way, Madam. As Kate leads Mary and her Ladies down an adjacent hall, Moray’s smile fades. He turns to Bothwell.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Do you intend to stay as well?

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: I swore an oath to the Queen’s mother to protect her.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: She is well protected here.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: I shall uphold my oath just the same.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: And what reward does your loyalty command?

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: I am driven by duty, not ambition. A scoffing and dismissive half-smirk from Moray. He doesn buy it for a moment. INT. HOLYROOD - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - NIGHT The room is lit by several candles, but still dim. It’s completely empty. Mary looks around, taking in the barene

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: We are having a bed brought from town.  10A. Mary points to a wall, addressing the Servant--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My mother’s was here?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Yes, Madam.  11. And with this the Servant’s voice breaks. She can’t stop tear from rolling down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My apologies... Mary goes to her--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Her Majesty was too young to recall... (puts a palm to her chest) ...but I was your wet nurse. You’re so beautiful. Like your mother. Mary offers her a warm, compassionate smile.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (embarrassed, to escape--) With permission - I will make certain the bed. Mary nods. Kate exits the chamber. Mary turns to the Four Marys, who are trying to hide their mortification at the gloomy environs.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: A dire vrai, ce n’est pas une autre France. (It is no France.) She offers this as humour, and the Four Marys force a lau but it’s not very convincing. Then quite seriously--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mais notre devoir n’est plus 4 la France. C’est ici qu’il nous améne. (But our duty is no longer to France. It is here.) The Four Marys stop smiling. It’s a solemn reminder that their lives are forever changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is seated while an ARTIST paints a miniature portrai her. The Four Marys are overseeing ATTENDANTS who are in process of hanging tapestries on the walls. Mary is begin to make the place her own. Moray is with her.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Emperor Ferdinand looks to wed one of his sons...  12.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Are we to bow to the Hapsburgs?

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: They are a good family. Quite powerful.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And would require me to leave Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: A small price for such a favorable union. She turns to him--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Favorable for whom? They lock eyes for a moment. On Moray, clenching his jaw. Mary notices something on the far side of the room beyond Moray. Stands--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Higher. And we see she’s referring to one of the tapestries being hung on the wall. The Attendants raise it a foot.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This one. Mary watches as the ATTENDANTS climb down from their ladd and move the tapestry over to the new wall. As they place ladders, they raise the tapestry--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you. (to Moray) Better - is it not?

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: (stifling his annoyance) I know nothing of these matters. She takes his hand. Warmly--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You have done us a great service as ward over this realm. We would be wise to follow your example. Let us dispense with marriage for now and talk of governance. Those are matters which you know far better than myself. He forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate your confidence in me. She glances back up at the tapestry, decisive.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. Hang it here. She heads back over to sit before the Artist.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Continue.

dialogues.speaker: ARTIST
dialogues.text: Chin higher. We are TIGHT on the Artist’s POV as she tilts We CUT FROM this visage of her face to--
her chin up. Her portrait. A small one. Held in the light by BESS OF HARDWICK, Elizabeth’s lady in waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What do you see Bess? We PULL BACK. Elizabeth is studying the miniature along w Bess as the other ladies in waiting make final adjustment Elizabeth’s appearance - placing rings on fingers, powder her face--

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Charming. Fair - if the painter does not lie. Arrogant, perhaps. I do not like the look of her. (beat) And you?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Young. Clever. (beat) Confident. Looks down at her hand as a Lady places a ring upon it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She would have no trouble securing a husband, even without her throne.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Nor would you, Madam. Elizabeth turns to her, eyes flashing--  14.

dialogues.speaker: BESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forgive me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COURTIERS are crammed into the room, waiting for Elizabet emerge. This is one of the few times of the day that they have direct access to the Queen. It’s all about jockeying position, being seen and seeing others. Among those in court are the EARL OF LENNOX and his hands 17 year-old son, HENRY DARNLEY, straining to get a prime near the door to the Queen’s chambers. As Lennox tries to edge his way forward--

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: (to Darnley) Come. Closer. We SHIFT TO right by the door to the Queen’s chambers whe we find Cecil and Dudley. They have a prime position beca they will escort her to the privy council chamber. They s in low tones so as not to be overheard.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: She will not accept my hand.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You cannot be certain.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: I know because I know her heart. The moment I betray it with ambition, I lose her heart.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Would you rather she lose her crown?

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: You exaggerate.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (growing impatient) How much blood has been spilled in Rome’s name? If a Catholic Queen bears a child before our own, have no doubt that blood will spill again. Muster your courage and save us from her reticence.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: What you claim I lack in courage, you lack in reason, sir. She will not have me.  14~.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Nor would I have a commoner be king of England if we were not desperate for an heir. But we must mould the clay before us.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: (insulted) I am no commoner.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Nor are you noble.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bess adjusts Elizabeth’s hair. Elizabeth holds out her ha and an attendant places a hand mirror in it. Elizabeth ho up the mirror and looks at her own reflection. We RACK FOCUS from the mirror to the portrait of Mary in background so that her blurred reflection and the portrai are side by side in the frame. Elizabeth lets her gaze li on the portrait for a moment, we RACK FOCUS back to the mirror as she looks at her face once again, then turns an presents herself to her ladies. With a matter-of-fact, discerning eye.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are with Cecil and Dudley again--

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: You should bring it up with her directly.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I have, many times.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Then there is your answer.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: On all other matters she follows my counsel. I have her trust, but you have her affections. However much it pains me, I am not above admitting you wield a power I do not. You can succeed where I-- But before he can finish the sentence, the doors to the Queen’s Chamber open, revealing Elizabeth. The COURTIERS bow as they part to form a diagonal path ac the room. Elizabeth turns to Cecil and Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Cecil) Good morning, William.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Madam. She turns to Dudley, and saying it with far more warmth--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Robert.  15A.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: (as warmly) Resplendent.  16. Elizabeth smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Would you? He holds out his arm. She loops hers within his. They beg to walk along the path, Cecil falling in closely behind t with Bess and the Ladies. A bit of jostling among the Courtiers to be closest to th path. It’s not unseemly - they are Nobles and need to maintain their dignity - but it’s noticeable. As Elizabeth walks, she nods to some, ignores others. Len presses forward, Darnley following. As Elizabeth approach Lennox makes a show of a deep bow, but it goes intentiona unnoticed by Elizabeth. Lennox tries to recover by appealing to Cecil once Elizab has passed, stepping out in front of him. He keeps his vo low so as not to be overheard--

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: My Lord - I would ask our mistress to beseech Queen Mary that I be allowed to return to Scotland as Earl of our ancestral--

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (the gall, full volume) This is not the place.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: (insistent) It would be wise to have a Catholic servant there. My influence would--

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It is your influence which emboldened papists here. This is said loud enough for the entire room to turn its attention to Cecil and Lennox, which is what Cecil wants. Even Elizabeth turns and looks back. Lennox is red with embarrassment. Cecil and Dudley continue on. Lennox looks around and sees all eyes staring at him. Elizabeth exits the room and the crowd begins to dissolve low tones to his father--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: You humiliate yourself. Without hesitation Lennox turns and slaps his son hard ac the face. Darnley reels, stunned. Lennox heads for the ex Now it is Darnley whom the remaining Courtiers are starin at.  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on a young Italian Man - RIZZIO - playing the Renaissance Violin with accompaniment. He is comely, and talented musician. The chamber is still in the process of being decorated - more modest in its architecture and furnishings than what saw in Hampton Court, but still brighter and more luxurio than when we first saw the castle. The Four Marys are staring at Rizzio with admiration, eve perhaps a bit of lust. He smiles at Livingston, who looks her feet while blushing. The other Marys giggle, drawing attention from some of the NOBLES who are waiting in a li to kiss Mary’s hand. Among those passing by is MAITLAND - a high-ranking Noble diplomatic and innocuous on the surface, but a snake with He and Fleming lock eyes - an instant attraction. Moray introduces the guests to Mary as they come before h

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: William Maitland of Lethington, Secretary of State. Maitland turns his attention back to Mary. Kneels down an kisses her hand. Next up is KNOX - a Protestant Cleric, severely dressed w an even more severe manner. MORAY (CONT’D) John Knox, Church of Scotland. As Knox bends down to kiss Mary’s hand, Rizzio screeches bow across the strings of his renaissance violin - a comi sound. Knox turns back to Rizzio with disgust. The Four M giggle, and Mary herself cannot help but smile.

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: A loose string. Although this thin excuse does nothing to placate Knox. M veers things back to business--

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Let us begin. The Lords sit down on chairs in a semi-circle around the throne. Once they are settled, Mary addresses them in Fre

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Il est certain que beaucoup d’entre vous ne vous alliez qu’ad regret a une Reine Frangaise et Catholique. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (We are certain many of you are ill at ease aligning yourself with a French and Catholic Queen...) Some of the other Lords look askance at each other in reaction to her speaking a non-native language.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (she abruptly switches to Scots) But your Queen is in Scotland now. She pauses, letting her use of Scots sink in. Then--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When my beloved Frangois passed to God, I could have married any number of suitors. Portugal. Denmark. Sweden. Many others. The Hapsburgs offered their sons. (beat) I declined them all. On Moray. He’d much prefer she be married off.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just as I would not have an uncertain fate imposed upon myself, I will not impose an uncertain fate upon my subjects. (beat) They remain free to worship however they so choose, Catholic or Protestant. A look of surprise from the assembled Lords. This is not they were expecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is at the head of the table. Cecil speaks on be of his fellow Counsellors, which include Dudley and Rando

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Her pronouncements mean nothing. Whom she marries speaks louder than any edict from the throne.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Randolph) What say’st our Ambassador?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She feigns disinterest, Madam... 19.  Green Revisions (18.10.17) 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randolph - in stiff formality - concludes his report.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: She is formidable, Madam. On Elizabeth - she grimaces at this assessment of her riv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary before her Lords, as before.  21.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Pastor, you look displeased with our tolerance? A general nervousness flutters among the Lords, not least all with Moray, but Knox is not the least bit intimidated

dialogues.speaker: KNOX
dialogues.text: Any realm that is ruled by the Pope is not tolerant, Madam. It is enslaved--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Stand when I address you. Knox makes a show of standing slowly, resolutely and sayi the following words with equally slow resolve.

dialogues.speaker: KNOX
dialogues.text: There is one true God. And therefore one true religion.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Such rhetoric incites revolt.

dialogues.speaker: KNOX
dialogues.text: If a Prince strays from God’s will, it is not in doubt that they may be resisted. And in your case, as with all women: their sight is but blindness; their strength, weakness; their counsel, foolishness; their judgment, frenzy. Are we to abide a papist and a woman both? Mary is stunned, but gathers herself to have the last, if shaky, word--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well then, I perceive that my subjects shall obey you, and not me. And shall do what they like, and not what I command. And so must I be subject to them, and not they to me. Unwavering, and unmoved--

dialogues.speaker: KNOX
dialogues.text: May I sit, Madam?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. You may remove yourself from this council and my court. A gasp of unease from the other Lords. Knox, with all the pride he can muster--  22.

dialogues.speaker: KNOX
dialogues.text: My council is among the faithful disciples I serve. We have as little need of this court as it has of us. I pray for your soul, Madam. Knox slowly makes for the door, milking his exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary walks briskly with Moray. She can no longer contain rage - face flushed, speaking as briskly as she walks--

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: I beg you to reconsider. He has the trust of the people.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Did I not give deference to his faith?

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Yes. But we must be delicate. Allegiance does not happen by proclama-- She stops and turns to him, her rage frothing--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And where is his delicacy? That he should speak to a monarch so? Would he challenge Elizabeth thus?

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: With what cause? He would welcome a Protestant Queen. Which is precisely why we must not push him into her arms. Show him love.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You are wise, brother. There are times for wisdom. And there are times for love. But there are also times for strength. She continues on. Off Moray, swallowing his frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sparse, undecorated place of worship, clearly Protestan Knox stands at a pulpit, delivering a sermon. The front r are filled with nobility, including Maitland, who is sitt in the first row, listening with great interest.  23. As the rows progress toward the back they are populated w MERCHANTS and PEASANTS. It’s a packed room, and some of t peasants are forced to stand in the rear by the open door the street. This is part religious fervor, part retributi at having been removed from court--

dialogues.speaker: KNOX
dialogues.text: (with force) We have a scourge upon our land. ‘Tis worse than pestilence or famine. ‘Tis worse than the Roman pagans or Egyptian pharaohs. ‘Tis a woman with a crown who only pretends to worship Christ when in truth she kneels before the Pope. We will not bow as she does. Murmurs of approval from the congregation. Knox’s charism forcefulness picks up steam--

dialogues.speaker: KNOX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We do not pray to false idols. We do not take instruction from Rome. We resist those who would tempt us with indulgences. Deny those who worship luxury. Respect not those who flaunt their excesses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Four Marys are helping Mary undress. The room is now appointed with furniture and tapestries.

dialogues.speaker: KNOX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...who whore themselves to wealth and the degradations of the flesh. Mary taps Fleming’s cheek with her finger.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Alors, ici? (What about here?) The girls are laughing. Fleming blushing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (taps Flemings’ nose) Ici? (Here?)

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: (through her laughter) Non. (No.) Mary puts a finger to Fleming’s lips.  24.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Il vous a embrassé ici? (Has he kissed you here?)

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) Une fois (Once...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others gasp, titillated.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--Sans aller plus loin. (...But no further.)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (turning to Beaton) Et vous alors? Ils embrassent comment, les Anglais? (What about you? How well do the English kiss?)

dialogues.speaker: BEATON
dialogues.text: (smiling, embarrassed) Madame... Mary turns on a dime, suddenly serious.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What matters have you discussed with the Ambassador between your kisses? A chill between them all. The undressing has halted.

dialogues.speaker: BEATON
dialogues.text: Méme s’il y a de l’amitié entre lui et moi-- (We are friendly, but I--)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Fleming) Or you - with my Secretary of State.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Madame - vous savez que nous-- (Madam - you know we--)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: In Scots.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Our loyalty is to you alone. Mary warms, thawing the chill--  25.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I jest. I know you love me. But was she jesting? They resume undressing her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just be wary of these men. Their love is not the same as their respect. The Mary’s remove layer upon layer, down to her smock. Af several beats--

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Might I ask - since we have not known it ourselves... (gathers the courage) What is it like...? Less ashamed to complete the question than Fleming to ask

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: To have a man? INT. HAMPTON COURT - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - NIGHT Atop the bed with drapes drawn for privacy. Elizabeth wit Dudley. Her sleeves have been removed. The farthingale beneath her dress bulges up as they sit side by side. Dudley gently pushes the smock sleeve up Elizabeth’s fore revealing the skin of her wrist. He brings it to his mout and kisses the underside. Elizabeth closes her eyes, shak from the touch. Lips on skin is forbidden and thrilling.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have only lain with Frangois... INT. HOLYROOD - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - NIGHT Mary with the Marys. They’re still undressing her--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He shook terribly from fright. As did I. The poor boy did his best...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC rises from a DANCE. Two hands, palms flat to each o - a man and woman's...

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--but it was over before it began.  26. BACK TO Mary in her bedchamber with the Marys--

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: So you never...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. We tried but once. BACK TO the Banquet Hall - TIGHT on Mary’s glowing face, flushed from the thrill of a man’s touch--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yet I found myself...stirred, a wanting like none other... We PULL BACK to see that she’s dancing with Bothwell--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not so much for him... Then gliding to another Nobleman, then another, her face warmed by the music and hundreds of candles that fill the room. As she whisks between the men--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-but for the thing itself...the touch...skin upon skin. INT. HAMPTON COURT - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - NIGHT The MUSIC from the DANCE continues as-- Dudley is kissing Elizabeth’s nape, beginning to unloosen corset, but Elizabeth pulls away. Dudley reluctantly lets go of the strings. Takes Elizabet hand and brings it between his legs.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Do you feel my passion?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Quiet Robert. The music slows to something more elegaic and sparse as s withdraws Dudley’s hand. Disappointment on his face. Sile We POP to Bess and the Ladies in Waiting outside the drap tilting towards the drapes to see if they can overhear th whispers within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marys are rapt, gathered around Mary as she sits on t foot stool of her bed, now down to her smock.  27.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I should like to marry again. To know what it means to have a man fully. But... And we see her shift from revery to cold prudence--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -..-not if I am owned. The music STOPS. A beat. Mary stands.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall we sleep?

dialogues.speaker: SETON
dialogues.text: You're early... Following Seton’s gaze, Mary looks down. Sees a splotch o blood seeped through at her groin.

dialogues.speaker: BEATON
dialogues.text: I’ll get a fresh cloth. As Beaton gets up we TIME CUT TO-- Mary surrounded by the Marys. Beaton with a swaddle in ha Seton with a basin and damp cloth.

dialogues.speaker: LIVINGSTON
dialogues.text: Levez les bras. (Lift your arms.) Mary lifts her arms, the three remaining Marys avert thei eyes as they begin to raise her smock above Mary’s head, no mortal is allowed to see a sovereign nude. CUT TO TIGHT on Mary's bare legs beneath the groin. We se trickle of blood running down the length of her thigh to knee. Seton washes the blood away with the damp cloth. CUT TO TIGHT on the basin as Seton wrings the cloth, bloo clouding the water within. INT. HAMPTON COURT - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - NIGHT TIGHT on two hands barely touching on white linen - their pinky fingers grazing one another--

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do not ask this of me.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If you wed her she is ours. We PULL BACK to see Elizabeth and Dudley laying side by s still fully clothed. They talk low so as not to be heard.  28.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: And what of us?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What us?

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: You, Elizabeth. And I, your Robert.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: One of those is a Prince. The other is... She does not finish. He waits, then--

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Is what?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Is merely my Robert.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: (with a hint of bitterness) Merely.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: With Mary you too become a Prince.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: If I am Noble enough to marry one Queen, I am noble enough for another. Dudley moves in - Elizabeth withdraws.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Elizabeth... I know it cannot be. (repeating himself) I know it cannot be.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: England is not Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rizzio is escorted into the room by an Attendant, a DOG circling at him, barking loudly. He holds his lute high a the dog leaps up, nipping at it. It’s late Autumn. Rain pelts the windows. They approach M and her four ladies seated on the ground before the fire indoor picnic with a sumptuous lunch.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Worry not. She’s harmless...  28A. Mary whistles. The DOG runs over to her. Mary feeds her a piece of meat from her plate. She pets the dog affectiona as she devours the meat.  29.

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: You requested music, your Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What accent is that?

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: Italian.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How is your command of French? With spirit, he launches into a popular Arbeau chanson--

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: Belle qui tiens ma vie Captive dans tes yeux, Qui m'as 1’ame ravie D'un sourire gracieux... Mary and the others clap with approval. Rizzio bows.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is your hand as good as your French?

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: (puzzled) My hand, Madam?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I must make love to a woman, and I would have a man’s hand to help me. One who is loyal like my friend here. --she says as she TIME CUT to TIGHT parchment. We see Madame, (Madam, runs her hand through the dog’s fur. ON Rizzio’s hand writing with a quill on the words in French that we hear--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ma bonne cousine... my good cousin...) We switch to English for the sake of clarity. And see Riz seated at a small table writing, Mary plucking grapes from a bundle while she reclines on a rug, dictating the letter-

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are two sisters bound by womanhood, two Princes on the same island, and ruling side by side must do with affection...

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: “In harmony” perhaps.  29A.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. I like that.  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary walks along the colonnade as we see flakes of snow floating down into the court. The Four Marys & Rizzio are with Mary's dogs, that are playing in the snow in the mid of the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...-ruling side by side we must do so in harmony. Not through a treaty drafted by men lesser than ourselves, but respecting each other’s rightful claims granted by God... She places her palm out and lets a flake fall on it--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As the first snow falls to the North...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on the HOOVES of a HORSE walking through a fresh blanket of snow as it continues to fall, leaving hoofprin

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...it is the same snow that will fall at your feet. CUT TO from ABOVE as the riderless horse is being led to entrance by a GROOM, snow covering the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: From the same heaven above, in service of the same Lord...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on the flat blade of a knife scraping along a lengt coloured paper, the paper curling as it does--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-And when the same spring flowers for us both... PULL back to see Elizabeth placing the curled paper into intricate quilling design of flowers on a painted board.  30A.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I hope we might meet in person, that I might embrace you...  31. We TRACK UP to on Elizabeth’s face, warmed by the fire.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .-+-and we might resolve our destinies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is pacing, dictating a letter to a nearby SCRIB

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We would delight in holding our sister’s hand in ours. Already its warmth can be felt with your words... A knock on the door. She looks over--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth comes outside to the front entrance, where Dudl and Randolph are already sitting atop their respective horses, ready to depart on a journey, GROOMS nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Let us settle on a meeting place before the summer brings discomfort. During the following, Elizabeth approaches Dudley. He loo forlorn. Takes his hand in hers and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Let our nations cherish each other as we would - two Kingdoms united. He opens his hand to find one of her quilled flowers with it. It makes departing that much more difficult. She offe him a bittersweet smile.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Meanwhile accept this portrait as a sign of thanks for yours... But Dudley does not return the smile. He cannot hide his unhappiness at being charged with this mission.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And please accept this suitor who presents both his love and mine. As he begins to ride away, Elizabeth turns to watch him g and as the camera comes around on her we CUT TO--  31A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley presents the portrait of Elizabeth to Mary. Randol is in attendance, as are Moray and Maitland. Mary is delighted to receive the gift - beaming with excitement.  32.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...The Earl of Leicester - Lord Robert Dudley. Mary looks up from the portrait to address Randolph--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you think it might stand with my honour to marry my sister's subject?

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: (glancing to Dudley) It is true that an Earl is not a Prince... We POP to Dudley, who looks miserable, then back to Rando RANDOLPH (CONT’D) Surely there can be no greater honour than to match yourself with a Nobleman by whom you inherit such a kingdom as England. Moray perks up at this, as does Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I have such inheritance by blood, regardless of who I marry or do not marry. A provocation. Moray is anxious. Randolph remains cool.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Dudley) We must discuss succession before marriage, not the other way around. Randolph grits his teeth. This meeting is a failure for h

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We hope we do not vex the Earl.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Not in the least, Madam. I am grateful for your honesty.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Were I not a prince, I could not hope for a finer and more handsome man than you.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: You save me from disgrace. Off Mary’s look--  32A.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would be no more than a wretch compared to the beauty you possess. Mary laughs. With a flirtatious smirk--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We see why our cousin is so fond of the Earl. Then, on a dime, all business--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Randolph) I shall respect Elizabeth's crown as soon as she names me its successor.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: The issue of succession is a--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: For two years now we have dallied when the compromise could not be clearer. Elizabeth need merely agree to it.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Madam - my Queen will not be pleased by your rebuff of the Earl and your persistence regarding--  33.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: If she has any concerns about this proposal she may express them to me directly. Plans proceed for us to meet next month?

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Aye, Madam. In York.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Very well. We shall accomplish far more without envoys between us. A slight to Randolph, and we can read it in his eyes. She turns to Dudley again. Holding up the portrait of Elizabe

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (back to Dudley) How like is it unto your mistress’s face? INT. HAMPTON COURT - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - DAY Elizabeth is in bed. She looks pale and sickly. Bess wipe her forehead with a damp rag as Cecil addresses her. Rand and Dudley are with him.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: You must not meet with her, Madam. False affections are one matter, but giving her audience is--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What makes you think our affections false? Elizabeth’s voice is feeble from illness.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Affections aside, she remains obstinate. (glances to Dudley) And rebuffs your chosen one.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What sayst thou, Robert?

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: (falling in line) I agree with Cecil’s counsel.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: We are all agreed Madam. Elizabeth looks grim. Dudley gives a glance to Cecil, indicating that perhaps they should go and let him handle this.  33A.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Rest well, Madam. He and Randolph exit. Dudley remains. Sits down on the ed of the bed and takes her hand and kisses it.  34.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: I survived it as a boy.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And if I should not survive?

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: You will.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And even so - if my face is scarred, will you still love me?

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: I would love you if you turned into a fish. Elizabeth starts to chuckle. Dudley brings his hands to t sides of his neck to mimic a fish. She laughs more, painfully. Then her brow furrows. Vulnerable--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Is she as beautiful as I hear told?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Mary’s face, windswept and vigorous, as she ride through the lush, late spring countryside. Her entire entourage is on the move. We see her taking in the beauty the land, a smile on her face as she basks in the sun. The spell is broken by--

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Halt. The entire party comes to a stop. Mary looks ahead and se contingent of three horsemen galloping toward them from d the road. Two appear to be soldier escorts. Bothwell race ahead with four horseman of the Royal Guard to intercept. As Bothwell’s contingent nears the foreigners they come t stop. From Mary’s POV we can barely make out that one of is Randolph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Royal entourage is in the background. Mary walks thro a field of grass and wildflowers at some distance, Randol next to her, Moray and Maitland several steps behind.  35.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Could her Council not wait until her return?

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Their business was urgent, Madam. The Huguenots sent an envoy.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (concerned) And she receives them?

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: England wishes no more bloodshed. Being from France you must understand.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You may tell my sister that we pray for swift peace, that we may meet soon.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: I will tell her at once.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Stay with us the night back at Holyrood. I’m certain Mistress Beaton would welcome your company. Randolph blushes at the insinuation..

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Thank you, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO--
dialogues.text: Mary walking with Moray and Maitland toward the carriage the entire entourage is being turned around for the journ back. Three of her ladies - Seton, Livingston and Fleming close behind. Beaton is a bit farther back, walking with Randolph as he leads his horse on foot.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: She hides behind her Council.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You do not think she postpones...

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: I think she has no intention to meet until you recognise her legitimacy.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (sinking in) A false promise then.  35A.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Retaliation perhaps, for refusing the treaty.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: For refusing Dudley. Off Maitland’s look.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a matter of the heart, not the state. They don’t mix well. She glances back at Beaton and Randolph. They are smiling happy. Then turns to the ladies.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t you say, Mistress Fleming?

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Pardon me, Madam?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (gesturing to Maitland) I speak of the state... (gesturing to Fleming) .-.and of the heart.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: I am afraid I don’t understand...

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: (bristling) Your mistress mocks our affections.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not so. They sometimes have value... As she returns to her horse she steals one more glance at Beaton and Randolph.  36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randolph and Beaton are in the shadows - groping, kissing rough and lustful. After several moments of this, Beaton squirms loose.

dialogues.speaker: BEATON
dialogues.text: It’s late. I must attend to my mistress. He tries to kiss her again but she holds him off.

dialogues.speaker: BEATON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think of your wife. He sighs. Just as she pulls away he grabs her wrist--

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Nothing we spoke of...

dialogues.speaker: BEATON
dialogues.text: Of course not.  37. With a smile she leans forward and gives him one last kis He lets go. She walks off. As she rounds the corner to a corridor she picks up pace, walking more and more briskly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaton enters, breathless. Mary is being undressed by the three other Marys.

dialogues.speaker: BEATON
dialogues.text: The pox, Madam. Off their looks--

dialogues.speaker: BEATON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is no envoy. She has the pox. On Mary. This changes everything.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How grave?

dialogues.speaker: BEATON
dialogues.text: Quite grave.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Beaton) Go rouse my brother. As Beaton exits, to the other three--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Back on with it. They hasten to re-dress her. Mary’s thoughts are swirling Several beats as she traverses exhilaration to doubt--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think me sinful?

dialogues.speaker: SETON
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My excitement.

dialogues.speaker: LIVINGSTON
dialogues.text: C’est Dieu qui la rend malade. (It is God who makes her ill.)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (in French, to herself) Oui, c’est Dieu. (Yes, God.) (in English) He has his plan...  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Rizzio as he transcribes with the scratch of a q against parchment. Moray looking over his shoulder. The r is lit by only candles, giving it a conspiratorial feel.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It will please you to know that I have warmed to the prospect of wedding Lord Dudley. We shall do SO... Rizzio dips his quill in the ink. We PULL BACK to see Mar dictating the letter--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .+.upon one condition. She waits for Rizzio to catch up, then--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: While we wish you a long and healthy life, and that no injury or illness befall you, we shall only do you the favour of betrothing your special friend... Rizzio is writing furiously. Once again Mary waits for hi catch up. She stands and goes over to Rizzio so that she look over his shoulder as Moray and Maitland are doing--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .»».once you name us heir. INT. HAMPTON COURT - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - DAY Elizabeth is covered now with small pox boils. She is attended to by Bess as two other ladies keep vigil as she reads the letter from Mary.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (in a whisper, to herself) She knows...

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: Madam...? Leaping to another thought, this one fueled by jealousy--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: My “special friend”...she taunts us. Her gut is churning; she’s half delirious from her illnes  39.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She wants him as her own. My Robert. My crown... PRELAP the clashing of fencing sabers as we CUT TO--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A number of NOBLES are stripped down to their undershirts fencing in pairs down the length of the gallery as others look on. In one pair is Dudley. In another is Darnley. Th door flings open, revealing Elizabeth. The fencers cease. Everyone stares at her - surprised to their Queen enter unannounced and in such a sorry state.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Out. The Nobles begin to disperse, the fencers setting down th foils as they go. Some are stealing glances at Elizabeth they exit, particularly Darnley. Dudley approaches her, concerned-— She hands him the letter. He begins to read. Looks up at He lifts her veil so he can see her better. She looks stricken, on the verge of tears. Her eyes say “You must n leave me.”

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: I am yours. Forever yours.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: But how? Am I to refuse her what I myself suggested. Her tears begin to fall. Dudley embraces her to console h She would normally feel embarrassed by such an outward si of emotion, but not in his arms. After a beat, in a whisp

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: There is a way to right this... She looks to him - expectant, hopeful--

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The boy, who was fencing nearest to the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I took no notice.  40.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Darnley, son of Lennox...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Mary, two hands covering her eyes. Giggles in th background. She’s smiling. We PULL BACK to see that Beato covering her eyes from behind.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Now. Beaton removes her hands. We CUT TO Mary’s POV: Fleming a Livingston are holding one of Mary’s dresses up to Rizzio fanning out the hem, Seton holding the blouse up to his chest. Rizzio begins to twirl as if dancing the masque with effeminate physicality, the three women keeping the dress blouse against him as he does, singing in a falsetto. Mar laughs as do the other women.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You look exquisite, Mademoiselle. Rizzo curtsies, with a feminine voice--

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: Is it a sin that I feel more a sister to you than a brother? The smiles of the women fade. Rizzio instantly backtracks

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (standing) Forgive me. I forget myself in your company. But Mary wants to relieve him of his shame.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Be whoever you wish with us. You make for a lovely sister. (to the ladies) Doesn’t she? The other ladies nod, feeling free to smile once again. W can sense Rizzio appreciates their acceptance. A knock at door. The ladies instantly pull the dress away from Rizzi

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Enter.  4l. The door opens, revealing Moray and an Attendant. He glan to Rizzio warily, then to Mary--

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: We have visitors. He hands Mary a letter from Elizabeth. She reads over it quickly - looks up at him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They are Stuarts...

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As an ATTENDANT shows Darnley and Lennox in, sotto voce--

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: I shall talk. You say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Not even to--

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: Silence. The Attendant steps aside. What Lennox and Darnley see ar Mary and the Four Marys on common stools. They are all dressed similarly, Mary no different than the others. Mor and Maitland are to the side.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: The 4th Earl of Lennox... Lennox bows. MORAY (CONT’D) His son Henry, Lord Darnley. Darnley bows. Lennox expects the Queen to say something, he cannot tell which of the five women is Mary. He looks Moray and Maitland for assistance. They are statues. He l to the Attendant, who says nothing. It’s an embarrassing position to be in. But neither offers guidance. He looks to the Ladies.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: Forgive me - I do not know my Queen’s visage. He gets no help from anyone. Lennox looks helplessly from Lady to the next.  42. He laughs nervously, both flummoxed and insulted. But Dar is amused, and more than game to play. He walks forward brazenly.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Let me, father. As he speaks he circles the women slowly, considering the His charisma is electric, amplified by how closely he orb almost brushing up against the women, his proximity and t chance of physical contact so acute it’s thrilling. He sp slowly, confidently - his voice intoxicating - we see the womens’ chests rising and falling, titillated. Darnley continues to circle them...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I give you verse, unsheathing my quick wit...to see which among you it quickens. Giggles from the ladies. Moray and Maitland remain icy co

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But should I fail to choose correctly... As he comes around the front of them again, he places his hand on his chest, feigning sorrow--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tis my soul that will be sickened. They smile at his performance, thoroughly charmed.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For shame returning to my native land...Only to be deprived of kissing... Now he stops and kneels before Seton... But at the last moment he turns to Mary, takes her hand--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .«.-my Queen’s perfect hand. He bends forward and gives her hand a tender kiss. The ot Marys clap with approval. Darnley rises and bows.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: You held your breath when I was about to err.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Darnley walking alone, the Four Marys trailing i the distance--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: The request was ours and she was kind enough to grant us passage. Here we can worship as we choose.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I doubt tis faith that brings you. Rather the lands your father seeks. Or even the throne.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: The throne?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why would Elizabeth grant you passports if she did not intend you as a suitor? And by laying suit to me does not the House of Lennox lay suit to all of Scotland? Darnley chuckles. Mary is offended. She stops, turns to h

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I amuse you.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Aye. (A beat) Madam - you must not be Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: The woman lives in fright - always suspecting intrigue, always fearful of revolt.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Her fears are wise. We both have Nobles who would have us deposed. Darnley takes the scolding without showing an ounce of regret. The opposite. He smiles back at her.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Have I vexed you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary self-consciously brings her fingers to her cheek and turns away. Darnley places a hand on her face and turns h towards him. It’s an incredibly bold gesture.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You dare touch a sovereign without her permission? Though she says this, she makes no effort to remove his h

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: I can speak for neither my father nor Elizabeth. Only for myself. He moves his hand so that his palm rests on her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And speaking for myself, you have a loyal subject in your Henry, who would rather worship at your feet than at a Catholic mass. He leans in to kiss her on the lips. She turns her head a just before his lips reach hers. Continues walking, her c heaving from the close encounter. Darnley begins to follow, several steps behind.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I shall keep walking with you then, until you object. Mary keeps walking, unsure how to answer, a swirl of emot Darnley catches up. Offers his arm. She takes it. And the continue to walk in silence - Mary’s vigilant mind battli with the longing in her body. We hear the sound of lute strings being plucked and CUT T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seton leads Darnley up a spiral staircase by candlelight. they reach the top of the stairs she pauses, seeing shado Gestures for Darnley to stop. Blows out her candle. Two Nobles pass in the hallway, not seeing Seton and Darn in the shadows of the stairwell. Once they have passed, s gestures for Darnley to follow, and they continue on.  45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rizzio plucking the strings casually. The Marys (minus Se are attending to Mary, powdering her face, combing her ha dabbing her wrists and neck with oils. Rizzio looks on as plays, a smile of appreciation at her beauty. Mary’s eyes shine with anticipation and anxiety. The Mary step away to have a look at their labors. Rizzio - contin to play--

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: You glow, Madam. TIME CUT to Seton knocking on the door from the outside t make those within aware of their arrival. Seton and Darnley enter. The Marys curtsy and promptly ex Rizzio stays. Mary is not in sight. TIME CUT to Rizzio helping Darnley remove his collar, his sleeves and his doublet, so that he is only wearing his undershirt and breeches. Then Rizzio gestures to the bed-

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: You remain?

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: The Queen scarcely knows your grace. Rizzio picks up his lute, nearby.

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I shall play, and hear nothing. Darnley circuits the bed to the other side, where the dra are drawn open. Mary sits atop the bed, knees beneath her looking resplendent. Rizzio perches himself on a stool and begins to pluck the lute once more, his fingers matching the music that has continued to play throughout the sequence thus far. We CUT BACK to the far side of the bed. Darnley is still taking in Mary’s beauty.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (nodding to a side table) There is wine if you desire it. Darnley fetches the bottle and pours a goblet. As he does

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I refused you. I wish... She averts her eyes. She does not want to admit it. Glanc at the goblet of wine.  46.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I have some? He holds out the goblet. She reaches for it. But when her hand wraps around it, he places his other hand on hers. Caresses her fingers with his. An intake of air from Mary He slides her hand over the goblets rim, dipping her fing within. Then brings her fingers to his lips and glosses t wet with the sherry. Her mouth is parted, her breath quickening. His hand still on her wrist, he gently pulls forward. She closes her eyes and places her mouth on his. Then mov the tip of her tongue along the length of his lips, savou the wine on the tender flesh. He runs his hand through the hair at the nape of her neck pulls her closer still, so that now her lips are fully pressed against his. TIME CUTS as we see kissing grow more passionate. Mary is giving into a hunger she hasn’t indulged before - except Frangois, who wasn’t up to the task. There’s a ferocity t her desire, increasingly confident and instinctual. We see her run her hand along his leg, then between his thighs. When it finds its mark she pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you not...desire me? Darnley doesn’t waste a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Lie back. He gently lays her back. Kisses her collar bone, then her chest. Makes his way down to the folds of her dress. Push them up along her bare legs. She starts to retreat, grabbing his head by the hair and pulling him up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We cannot...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: We won't. I promise you. This is not that. She’s confused - not sure what he means.  47.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have faith in me. Do you have faith? She’s unsure but she wants to trust him. The fearless sid her takes over. She nods. Darnley lowers himself again, his mouth against the thin fabric of her gown wrought between her thighs. We CUT TO TIGHT on her face as she gasps, his mouth aligh her through the gown, an intense sensation beyond which a she thought possible, and she is utterly lost in it. We C

dialogues.speaker: TO--
dialogues.text: her hand clawing at the sheets her teeth clenched as she sucks in air her torso twisting her eyes widening her back arching her face as she convulses, gasping As her body shivers - the after shocks still rippling thr her, Darnley slides up beside her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you need to...?

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: No. Don’t worry about me. He gets up and pours two goblets. Walks around to the oth side of the bed where Rizzio is still plucking. Sets one goblet down for Rizzio. They lock eyes. Then Darnley heads back around and sits down in a chair. Takes a sip as he looks over to Mary, who is now on her s her back to him. On Mary, heart pounding, slipping into reverie, but also trying to process what just occurred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth at the head of the table, her counsellors assembled. She has recovered from her small pox, but she still looks pale and thin, and right now she is on the defensive. Cecil and Dudley are in attendance.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Without a treaty signed, this union strengthens her claim.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You need not condescend. We are well informed.  48.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Forgive us. We merely seek to protect your crown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary rides on horseback, flanked by Moray and Maitland an small party of Nobles and Guards in tow. They are on a da trip to Arthur’s Seat.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: You cannot wed him, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I do not wed him blindly. He has promised no ambition.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: He understands that he would only be your consort? Not a King outright?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He does.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: I find it difficult to believe that any man would settle for as much. We INTERCUT between these two scenes--

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Two Catholics wed. Two Stuarts, Madam...

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: He has a claim of his own, even without betrothal. Together they make a union of two claims.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: She has a chosen an Englishman, as I asked. What recourse do I have?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Implore her to marry Lord Dudley. He was your first choice. Elizabeth looks to Dudley, who looks back sympathetically

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Dudley is her puppet. He offers no advantage.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Unless she promises to make you heir.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (blood up) Where is this promise? That has failed to appear these past four years?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I will not offer my Lord if it means naming her successor.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: She will not accept him otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Then let her refuse him.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: On succession I agree. But Darnley imperils us more.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: He would provoke revolt among our Nobles.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (a sharp blow) Do you command so little respect that you could not discourage them?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: We must not delay. You must forbid this marriage. On Elizabeth, pondering this. Then she abruptly stands. T Councillors follow suit. She exits without another word. Cecil turns to Dudley with venom on his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What chaos you have brought to us.  50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and the others are nearing the crest. On Darnley galloping fast on his horse past the other Nobles. He whirls around on his horse as he gets to Mary, canteri and stepping his horse sideways before her. Moray and Maitland eye him with the same contempt with wh Cecil beheld Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: (pointing ahead) Is that the top?

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Aye. As he turns his horse to trot ahead--

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: No subject should ride before his Queen. Darnley glances back. It’s a barbed comment, reminding hi that would he marry the Queen he is still but a subject. dispels any conflict by trotting ahead of Darnley.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Would he?

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Though he would. Mary starts to pick up speed. Darnley accepts the challen keeping near, just a neck behind her. And now the two are galloping up the crest, a thunder of hooves between their horses. CUT TO Mary and Darnley alone atop their horses at the cr of Arthur’s Seat. Edinburgh and the countryside beyond stretches out before them.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How it must feel...to rule all that is within your sight.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I am but its servant. Darnley looks to her, not quite understanding. She contin to gaze out at the view beneath. He looks back out. A bea and now she turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you prepared to be its servant?  51. Looking back at her, eyes ablaze. Does she mean what he thinks she means?

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: It is right for the man to ask.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then ask. He takes her hand and brings it to his mouth, softly...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Before God... Kisses her hand lightly...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Before all of Scotland... He leans in, whispers in her ear...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Before all the world... He kisses the side of her neck. The touch of his lips sen a jolt through her--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. Into her ear again--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: You will be my Queen?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: And I your King?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. And whispering into her ear--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Your master. She pulls back and looks him in the eye. A slight correct but smiling--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My husband. He laughs - giddy, joyful, not necessarily absorbing the correction for what it was.  52. She laughs in return, squeezes his hand. They both turn a once again gaze out upon the view together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randolph stands before Mary, Moray and Maitland are prese

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: They are English subjects, Madam. If my Queen orders their return, they must.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She asked that I marry an English Nobleman. And now she deprives me?

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Her wish is that you should not marry this particular noble.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You may tell your mistress I shall do so, with or without her blessing.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Madam - before you act rashly, please consider--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It is enough my own Lords treat me as though I’m but a girl... On Moray, about to step forward, but Maitland holds him b

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will not be treated as such by Elizabeth. I will be the woman she is not. I shall produce an heir, unlike her barren self. Randolph is stunned silent and paralyzed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to an Attendant) Prepare the Ambassador’s horse. Randolph bows and makes for his exit. As he passes Beaton averts her eyes so as not to make contact with his. As so as he is gone, Moray steps forward, incensed.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: (temper flaring) Reckless child. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
