dialogues.text: I have worked too long and too hard with too much bloodshed to secure peace in our land. Do not let your curséd passion rule you. 52A.  53.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (calm and cold) Tis your voice raised, sir. And you would lower it in my presence. Moray has reached the breaking point, but he lowers his v - speaking slowly and purposefully.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: If my counsel no longer has value, then I am obliged to withdraw from court.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: If you must. Whether he is bluffing or not, she has called it. And fro the resoluteness in her eyes, both we and Moray know she not bluffing in response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold day. Both Elizabeth and Cecil are bundled up. Grey discomforting skies.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You have neither husband nor children. And you approach an age whereupon you cannot bear them... Elizabeth looks out to the horizon, despondent.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must confront the truth, Madam. Displeasing as it may be. In a softer tone, more as a friend than a councillor--

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have confronted that truth. She turns to him, surprised by the admission. Also softly

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You understand that I cannot.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Will not. And I accept it. Do I understand...?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No more than I understand God.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It is my choice. God would have a woman be a wife and mother.  54. Observational, not accusatory--

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: So you defy his will.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No - I choose to be a man. Off his look. He still fails to fathom her--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As children dream in their sleep after apples and in the morning, when they awake and find not the apples, they weep. Such a man as I might marry, finding himself disappointed, would not stop at weeping.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (finishing her thought) He would conspire.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No Prince's revenues be so great that they are able to satisfy the insatiable cupidity of men.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: This I understand.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Which is why you are the closest thing I shall ever have to a wife. He laughs at this. It’s a tender, intimate moment.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I shan’t mention your proposal to Lord Dudley. She laughs at this in return.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Come and take my hand. He comes over and takes her hand. It doesn’t feel romanti It feels fraternal.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would be lost without you. And now it’s he who looks out to the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: My father despised my first wife. Her name was Mary...  55.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: There are no shortage of those.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (chuckles ) Indeed not.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Despised her why?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: I married her for love. (beat) It was foolish. She had no wealth or influence. But I adored her. And when she died - it left me... He shakes his head, not wanting to complete the memory. B in his eyes we can see the devastation her death wrought. Elizabeth squeezes his hand. He forces the thought out of mind. His familiar coolness returns.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This world is a brutal place. It has no patience for such foolishness. (turns to her) We men must be wiser, mustn’t we?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Tell me what to do.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: We must make civil war in Scotland. Elizabeth ponders this, brow furrowed, eyes darkening. Th affection has shifted back into realpolitik. Elizabeth removes her hand from Cecil’s.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You would have me depose a sister monarch?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It is either civil war there. Or civil war here. ON Elizabeth, weary. But a cold resolution comes over her Cecil has seen this look before. It’s what he hoped for.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I want to know nothing of it.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: The arrangements shall be mine alone. On Elizabeth's face as we hear the sound of BAG PIPES...  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Mary’s hand - three royal marriage rings upon it DARNLEY’S hand enters frame, similarly ringed. Mary place her hand on his. Drums strike up the dance. Pull back to reveal MARY and DARNLEY standing alone in th centre of the hall hand on hand. The wedding banquet is o the tables are pushed back and the wedding guests stand around the hall watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fishing trawler is being dragged on the shore, its good covered in burlap to shield them from the rain. Nearby on rise are the silhouettes of half a dozen hooded men on horseback. They begin to gallop down toward the wagons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wedding dance continues and Mary and Darnley are join by BETON, SETON & LIVINGSTON and their dance partners. FLEMING encourages MAITLAND to join the dance but he resi MARY notices MAITLAND. Other nobles decline to dance and on disapprovingly. Mary remains regal despite the lack of enthusiasm, althou we can sense it bothers her. Darnley, is less able to hid his displeasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DARNLEY downs his drink in one gulp and gestures to his servant to refill his goblet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the six horseman pulls back the burlap covering bo We see nothing but hay until the Wagon Driver pushes it a and reveals a cache of pikes, swords, crossbows and muske We also see a small trunk. The Nobleman opens it. The tru is full of gold and silver coins. One of the other men st forward to take a closer look. And within the hood we see that it is Lord Moray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty Male Guests dance in lines with military precision It’s quite formal choreography. But a very drunk Darnley inserts himself into the dance, sloppy and grinning. He i trying to get the dancers to bow to him, the king.  56A. The Dancers attempt to continue, but it’s difficult to navigate around him. On Mary, embarrassed by her husband. looks over to Rizzio, who is strumming his lute. Somethin should be done. Rizzio takes the cue. He strolls toward Darnley, still strumming, in a half-walk, half-dance - circles Darnley a though it’s all part of the choreography, then brings his arms around Darnley from behind, placing the lute at his chest, as though his arms are Darnley’s arms. Everyone laughs. It’s a comedic and graceful way to get Darnley ou the way. He spins Darnley as he’s strumming, walking him to the side, almost as if all of it were planned.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the drums continue over the pipes we see foot soldiers marching in a column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Mary watching something. We CUT TO her POV: It’s Darnley and Rizzio off to the side of the room, Darn on Rizzio’s lap, drunkenly letting him play the lute, laughing and plucking the strings himself. BACK ON Mary, perturbed by both Darnley’s drunkenness and Rizzio’s familiarity with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A continuation of Scene 78. The column of rebel soldiers passes by Knox, Moray with him. Knox is giving blessings they march past him, palm raised, mouthing “Bless you” an “In service of the Lord.” INT. HOLYROOD - DARNLEY’S CHAMBER - DAY TIGHT on Darnley’s face. He is passed out on his bed. A h SLAPS his face.  58. And with the slap the pipes and drums stop. Darnley opens his eyes, squinting. Sees Mary standing bef him. We see that Rizzio lays in the bed next to Darnley. Rizzio is stirring now. Is horrified to see Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Darnley) Rise and prepare yourself. As Darnley sits up he sees Bothwell in the door. Is surpr to see him in his Royal Chamber.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Be gone. But Bothwell doesn’t budge.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (turns to Bothwell) He is in your care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OFFICER is showing her how to load and cock a pistol. aims it at the wall and fires. With a loud BANG and puff smoke the lead ball leaves a small crater in the plastere facade. He turns back to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Now I shall try. He hands her the pistol, bag of gunpowder and a lead ball she prepares the pistol for it’s next shot, Rizzio - now dressed - emerges from within and approaches her. Livings intercepts him to prevent him getting to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: LIVINGTON
dialogues.text: Rentre! Tu n’es pas digne de son regard. (Go back inside. You are not worthy of her eyes).

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: Please...

dialogues.speaker: LIVINGSTON
dialogues.text: Non. Misérable! Canaille! (No. You wretch. You dog). (to the Guards) Battez-le comme un chien s’il S’approche encore plus. (He should be beaten like a dog if he draws nearer). But he tries anyway.  58A.

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: A word - a moment... Several Guards step forward to block him. Mary, witnessin all of this as she loads the pistol, finally speaks up--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Let him approach. The Guards step aside. Rizzio approaches her sheepishly. falls to his knees in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) To have betrayed you in this way - I have no excuse - And I beg...I beg that... She keeps her voice low as well. With some gentleness--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Stand.  59. He does.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have not betrayed your nature. He is anguished by her kindness.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I cannot fault you for succumbing to his charms as I did. (beat) But we must be more careful now. He nods, grateful for her mercy. She raises the pistol an aims at the wall. She pulls the trigger and BANG... On which we CUT TO-- EXT. MARY’S CAMP —- DAY Mary rides at the vanguard. She is fitted with armour and steel cap on her head, pistol in a saddle holster. Bothwe is similarly armoured and armed. Darnley rides a few yards behind them, wearing a gilded breastplate, looking pale and weary. Mary looks vibrant and at ease. She seems in her element, the move, the head of an army 10,000 soldiers strong.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Moray is marching southwest, toward Dumfries.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The English can easily supply them there...

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: If we make good time we could cut them off before they reach the gates. Or we fortify here and prepare for a siege, blocking the road south.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What would you have us do?

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Meet them and end this now.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Why give chase? Let them starve behind the walls of Dumfries.  59A.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: If we lose sight, they could flank us. I want to flank them first. There's a bridge they must use to cross Annan.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How far?

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Two days. But I can get us there in one.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Give the order. Bothwell turns his horse around and begins riding down th line, shouting the order for a quickstep. The entire colu begins to pick up speed, the foot soldiers marching more briskly. Mary wheels her horse around to follow Bothwell the line.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Why give chase? Let them come to us.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Are you afraid Henry?

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Good. Because our swords are not just for show.  60. And she yanks on the reins, trotting down the line. Off Darnley, emasculated and alienated. TIME CUT to Mary on foot, leading her horse by the reins, walking side by side with the common foot soldiers. As th walk briskly past her they each lower their heads out of respect. Three YOUNG SOLDIERS walk past. They look no old than 16. They’re shy when she addresses them.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whence come you?

dialogues.speaker: URIE CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: The Highlands, Madam. These two from Inverness. I’m from Thurso.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Fishermen?

dialogues.speaker: URIE CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I am sorry we have only mutton. Two of the boys smile shyly at this. The third (HECTOR MACLEAN), just smiles at seeing the other two laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MACDONALD
dialogues.text: We are happy to have anything to eat, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Catholic?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES MACDONALD
dialogues.text: (nervously) No, Madam. She looks to Urie. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Hector) And you?

dialogues.speaker: URIE CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: He don’t know Scots, Madam. Only Gaelic.  61.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tell him I’m grateful for his service.

dialogues.speaker: URIE CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Tha a’ bhanrigh taingeil airson do sheirbheis.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR MACLEAN
dialogues.text: Tha e moiteil a bhi na shearbhant don bhan righ agus tha e deonach basachadh air a son.

dialogues.speaker: URIE CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: He says he’s proud to serve his Queen. And to give his life if he must.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tell him: If any of us should die today, we all go to the same heaven.

dialogues.speaker: URIE CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Ma bhasaicheas duine againn an diugh, theid sinn dhan aon Neamh! Hector smiles at her and makes the sign of the cross. On Mary, grateful and inspired by the show of loyalty as the continue walking onward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s getting late in the afternoon now. We hear the stead beat of a REBEL DRUMMER giving tempo to the march. An impatient Moray berates his men. From a mound covered in twisted pine, we see the men trud along a curved track. Ahead of them is a bridge, which fo a fast-flowing river. Moray and his men are on its West B This, unbeknownst to Moray, is MARY’s point of view. The air is heavy with midges. The soldiers are fatigued lugging expensive, heavy muskets and weaponry: Cecil's supplies. Moray rides up and down the line, driving the troops forward. Frustrated, he commands the Rebel Drummer pick up the tempo.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Double it. The Rebel Drummer switches to a quick-step beat. The men start to pick up their feet. Again we see the track from above, where the road curves away from us at each end. MO spots an oncoming obstruction heading towards the bridge the East Bank of the river: a herd of Highland Cattle and four DROVERS.  61A. MORAY (CONT’D) (to the Rebel Drummer) Halt. The Rebel Drummer performs a flourish and stops drumming. troops halt. Moray and MORAY’S SECOND ride forward to pre the cattle from blocking the bridge. MORAY (CONT’D) Stand aside. We must pass. The four Drovers ignore his shouts and, as Moray and Mora Second reach the East Bank, the cattle flow around them, blocking the bridge and stranding Moray and Moray’s Secon the East Bank. As the herd of cattle flow across the bridge, the first o three loud, slow drumbeats is heard. At the first beat, t Rebel Army stutter forward. Mistaking the drumbeat for hi Rebel Drummer--

dialogues.speaker: MORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Halt I say! But the drum beat comes from JAMES MACDONALD, Mary’s drum who stands by MARY above the track. With the second, slow drumbeat, the Rebel Drummer looks around. It’s not him. Where is it coming from? He panics, throwing off his drum to aid his retreat. The panic is beginning to spread. What’s going on? This is an ambush. The third beat coincides with an order from Moray’s Secon MORAY’S SECOND Form up! Form up-- Mid-shout, he is unhorsed by a DROVER, who swings at him his droving stick. Mary’s men fall from above. It is a Highland charge. Deadly, simple, they stream down the hil from where MARY commands them, driving Moray’s men into t river. Moray’s men try to mount their heavy muskets and t aim but the Mary’s men are upon them. URIE CAMPBELL and HECTOR MACLEAN charge down the hill, Ur spots a musket take aim at Hector and pushes him out of t way, they both slip down the slope, avoiding the musket f find their feet and charge onwards. Moray’s men are hit hard from Mary’s side and driven into river. Escaping to the East Bank, they are met by more of Mary’s men, who have lain in wait, anticipating the men i the river. Marooned on the bridge, in the midst of Highland cattle, Moray looks from side to side of the bridge and sees his soldiers and their heavy equipment being lost and slaught in the river.  62. He sees his precious guns and powder floating and MORAY t to hack his way out of the cattle, attempting to get back his side. Seeing Moray slashing his way through the Highland cattle Bothwell leaves Mary's side. Moray arrives back at the We Bank, just to find his army deserting up the road away fr him. He is confronted by Bothwell, charging down the trac towards Moray. As Bothwell streams through the retreating soldiers, he dispatches three men, slicing through them. Moray panics, his trembling hands trying to load his gun. Back to Bothwell riding him down. In his panic Moray drop his gun, Bothwell is seconds from him. Just before impact Mary raises her hand. A bugle gives Bothwell the instruct to halt. Bothwell pulls up, nose to nose with Moray. Mora sees Mary on her mound, realising that she has mastermind the whole ambush. He looks back to Bothwell, who backs aw ushering Moray down the track to his retreat. In the river, we see Moray’s drum floating towards us as men flee. Moray rears his horse with one last look to Mar then gallops away in flight with his men. On Mary. She does not need to slaughter her brother or gi chase. She has accomplished what she needs to.  63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary rides triumphantly at the head of her column, glowin from her victory. Down the line, Soldier #3 leads a Gaeli chant. A rough and lovely song of praise. The whole troop joins in. Mary glances over at Darnley, who is waving bac accepting their affirmation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is being undressed by the Four Marys. They’re almost finished when there is a knock at the door. It opens, revealing Darnley. He’s visibly inebriated.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: You summoned? Mary nods to the Four Marys, who quickly exit. They close door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How much have you had?

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Celebrating our victory, my love. She goes to him - all business - and begins to unbutton t fly on his breeches.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? She slides her hand in and begins to stroke him. He pulls away. She places a hand on his chest. Gently--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. He does. She continues to stroke.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re almost there.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: I can’t...I’ve had too much to drink...  64.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Think of Rizzio. He opens his eyes, furious. Slaps her hard in the face. S reels, placing a hand to her cheek. He gets up and grabs by the wrist. Pulls her over to the bed and bends her ove pressing her face down into the sheets. While he’s holding her down he begins to jerk himself, to himself hard enough. Mary does not struggle. She wants a child, whatever she must endure to produce one. Sufficiently hard, Darnley pushes up Mary’s gown and begi to forcibly take her from behind. Mary winces. It’s painf It's degrading. But she knows it will be over soon. And it is - in less than 30 seconds. Darnley grunts with climax, then stumbles out of the room. On Mary, trying to hold back tears. It was awful, but she achieved what she wanted to. She climbs onto the bed and down on her back. Pulls her knees up to her chest. A few moments later the Four Marys re-enter. They see fro Mary’s position that the deed is done.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pray for me. The Four Marys kneel around the bed and lower their heads prayer. During which we begin to hear a PRIEST’S voice fr the high Latin mass...

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Incensum istud a te benedictum, ascendat ad te...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on the Priest swinging an incense thurible--

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: ..-Domine, et descendat super nos misericordia tua... The Latin continues as we watch the coloured light throug the stained glass windows traverse the floor in time-laps CUT TO TIGHT on the thurible as it swings. CUT TO TIGHT through a clear pane in the window, we watch flower bloom in time-lapse. CUT TO Darnley kneeling before the altar as the Priest conducts the mass.  65.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Accendat in nobis Dominus ignem sui amoris, et flamma aeternae caritatis. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Amen. The Priest hands the thurible to an ALTAR BOY. Turns to Darnley.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Shall I wait for her Majesty before I celebrate communion? Darnley looks behind him. The rest of the chapel is empty Abruptly he stands up and heads for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on Mary’s face as we hear Darnley pounding on the d From outside we hear--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We must speak, Mary. The pounding does not stop. We PULL BACK to see her layin the bed beneath the covers. Rizzio is sitting by her side holding her hand. She’s trying to ignore the pounding but won't stop. She turns to Rizzio--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Let him in. Rizzio goes the door. Undoes the bolt and opens it. Darnl is surprised to see him.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: What are you...?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Come, Henry. He brushes past Rizzio and goes to the bed. Rizzio and th ladies exit.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: You would have David here and bar your husband? Mary closes her eyes. She doesn’t want to be dealing with this. Darnley goes over to the seat where Rizzio was sitt A gentler tack, with a much softer tone.  66.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was at mass. I wished you at my side.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be attending Catholic service. It insults our Lords.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: When I am annointed they will afford me the same respect as you. Mary does not respond. Darnley gets anxious.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You promised. She still stays nothing. He pulls back the covers and pla his hand on her stomach. She’s clearly showing - now five months pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you have his father be nothing but a consort?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We know not if it’s a he. Darnley cannot check his temper any longer--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: I am more than a sire to a mare.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Please, I am tired...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Do you love me? Mary doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You are a Stuart. That matters more than love. We see fury in his eyes. But he needs her, so he has to dampen his rage.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, you are tired and know not what you say.  67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnley sits at the head table, an empty seat next to him dejected. The other guests are talking amongst themselves Then a hush. Heads swiveling. Everyone stands and turns t the main door. Mary’s ladies stand behind her. She looks resplendent. A smile, her face glowing with forthcoming motherhood. Her dress is equally stunning. There is no effort to hide the bump in her belly. As she makes her way to the head table the guests murmur each other, presumably about her pregnancy. She takes her place at Darnley’s side but remains standin address the guests. With infectious charm--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: If you have wondered where your Queen was these past few months, now there are no secrets. The whisperings can end. Spring comes bearing fruit. Laughter and applause among the guests.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My husband and I give thanks. She takes Darnley’s hand and smiles. He forces a smile in return. This is all for show.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With heaven’s blessing we bring another Stuart into this world, heir to Scotland...and to England. The addition of “England” is provocative. People begin to applaud, although some are too jolted to do so. We pop to Randolph, who turns to Maitland with shock.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: She speaks for herself.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Do her councilors fail to advise her?

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: We advise her endlessly, sir. Not that she heeds us.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: You must do better.  68.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Better than your own Queen’s council? Maitland has a point. More reflectively--

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: How did the world come to this?

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Wise men servicing the whims of women?

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: Aye... They look back toward Mary as the applause dies down. Darnley helps Mary into her chair, almost as if he’s a servant. He glances to his father, Lennox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth stares at a mare on the ground, a newborn foal laying beside her. A STABLE HAND is stroking the foal.

dialogues.speaker: STABLE HAND
dialogues.text: He’1ll make a fine stallion.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: STABLE HAND
dialogues.text: Of course, Madam. Elizabeth kneels down and pets the foal. It attempts to l its head but is still weak. A smile on Elizabeth’s face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil and Elizabeth walking.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: It is a clear provocation. She knew well Lord Randolph would report.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What would you have us do? Go to war over some reckless words?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Not us - her brother. He hopes to raise a second army. If we assist him...  69.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (firmly) As we did his first?

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (gingerly) I shall not fail you twice. Which is the closest he comes to an apology. She does not reply. Then calmly, but insistent--

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Madam, we cannot let her name your successor. She has no right.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: When I am dead and she is dead and you are dead, it matters not what names we said or did not say. The world will decide for itself. Cecil looks puzzled and disturbed. He cannot decipher her meaning, but he doesn’t like the tone of it--

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Now is not the time to soften... But Elizabeth is distracted by the sound of braying. She stops to look at the mare and the foal in the distance wi the Stable Hand. The foal is already on its feet, if wobb

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It’s a fine day, isn’t it? She tilts her face to the sun. Cecil is perplexed. She be to walk toward the mare and foal.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I shall see you inside. Cecil watches her go for a few moments, perplexed, then t and walks toward the palace. Elizabeth nears the horses, then stops, watching the foal suckle from its mother. She squints from the sun and rais hand to shield her eyes. Notices her own shadow. Looks do at it. Turns so that the shadow is in profile. Lowers her arms and pulls the front hem of her dress so that the sha shows a bulge where her stomach is. Considers this silhou for a moment, then drops the dress. She smooths the fabric flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is in a basin, receiving a bath. She is wearing a bathing gown in the water, as is custom.  70. The Four Marys attend to her, wiping her neck and arms wi damp cloths. Her belly rises just above the waterline lik dome.

dialogues.speaker: LIVINGSTON
dialogues.text: Vous lui donnerez quel prénom, si c’est une fille? (What will you name her, if it’s a girl?)

dialogues.speaker: BEATON
dialogues.text: Elizabeth. The women laugh.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Margaret, I think - after my grandmother. To remind her that she is as much Tudor as Stuart. (beat) She is also Henry’s grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Will you name it after him, if it’s a boy?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think not. He shares the same name as Elizabeth’s father.

dialogues.speaker: LIVINGSTON
dialogues.text: Vous lui donnerez peut-étre le prénom de votre propre pére? (Perhaps you name him after your own.)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (trying it out) James... She lets the name echo in her head. She likes it. Then--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh - Look...he likes it too... The women look at the dome of her belly poking above the water. There are small ripples across the surface from th baby kicking. All five women stare in fascination. PRELAP: The sound of HOOVES as we go TIGHT on the ripples

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is small and cramped. A cot, a simple desk and c and no more. Moray, only in his shirt, looks out a window something below, although we’re on him instead of what he sees.  71. He proceeds to put on his doublet to make himself more presentable as we hear footfalls coming up rickety stairs knock at the door. Moray opens it a crack to verify who i is, then lets the visitor enter. It’s a man in a hooded cloak. He pulls out a chair for the man, who removes his hood, revealing Lennox.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: Elizabeth could not do better? Moray ignores the slight. Sits down on the edge of the co Lennox sits across.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We too know what it is to be exiled.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: (straight to business) Your letter said you had a proposal.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: Have you burned it, as I asked? Moray reaches over to the desk and picks up a small plate covered with ashes--

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Once Mary bears a child... Dumps into the ground at Lennox’s feet. MORAY (CONT’D) There is no need for your son. As Lennox brushes some of the stray ash off his stockings

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: An infant cannot grant you pardon.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is right that you should return from exile. And it is right that my son should be King. Lennox looks back up - meets Moray’s eye with frosty shrewdness-—

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As King he would do what is right... INT. HOLYROOD - DARNLEY’S CHAMBER - NIGHT Maitland and Lennox address Darnley, who is staring into fireplace at the flames, drinking from a goblet.  72.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: David Rizzio. He is a liability to your rightful place as King. Darnley fetches a carafe to refill his goblet.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: Enough. These are serious matters. Darnley sets down the goblet, turns to Maitland.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Is it Bothwell who spreads these rumours?

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: Your sins are well known in court. You have done little to hide them.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: I have...when I drink...I do not know what I do...

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: (pivoting, gingerly) Let us not dwell on that. We speak of Rizzio’s relations with your wife.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: With Mary...? You are mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Does he not spend more time with the Queen than your grace? Why else would she make a common minstrel her private secretary?

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: It cannot be.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: (impatient) What matter if it be true?

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: I am not a cuckold.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: Would you rather the honest truth be told? That you are a sodomite? Darnley pales at the accusation. Lennox goes in for the k his impatience giving force to his voice--

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We must erase your sins, and either you are the adulterer or it is she.  72A. Maitland picks up a quill and holds it out to Darnley.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: The other Lords have signed. Darnley takes the quill and dips it in the inkwell, then bends over a parchment on the writing desk.  73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Conspirators head single file up the spiral stairs to Queen’s Chamber, Darnley and Lennox amongst them. Lennox looks sure of himself. Darnley looks hesitant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Rizzio, Seton and Fleming are playing cards in the small dining closet attached to the main room. TIGHT on the table as Rizzio lays down a jack of clubs. Mary lays down a king on top of Rizzio’s jack. Takes the trump with a smile. Rizzio shakes his head, smiling too--

dialogues.speaker: RIZZIO
dialogues.text: You've been saving that...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (teasing) It’s the only good card I-- But she’s interrupted by the sound of a door bursting ope the main chamber, followed by the sound of boots. Before she can even rise, Conspirators are pouring into t room. Maitland spies Rizzio in the dining cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: (to Rizzio) Come with me, sir. Mary is standing now. Steps in front of Rizzio as Darnley Lennox appear in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Stand aside.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You dare charge into my chamber unannounced and--

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: (to two Lords) Now. And the two Lords lunge with daggers, attempting to reach around Mary to stab Rizzio. The women scream. Mary is sho at the sight of the weapons.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I am with child... Lennox grabs Mary and pushes her toward Darnley.  74.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: (to Darnley) Take her. Darnley seems stunned himself, but pulls her out of the r Maitland, trying to set her at ease--

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: (to Mary) All that is done is the King’s own deed and action. He glances at Darnley as he says this. Mary glares at him The King? Darnley is pale and shaking. This is more than can take. Fleming is horrified that her lover has anything to do wi this. Moving toward Maitland--

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: William - what are you--

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Do not interfere. Two Conspirators make their way toward Rizzio. Fleming tr to get in the way of them, but Maitland grabs her by the wrist and yanks her aside. She falls to the ground. Rizzio cowers, begging for mercy, but the Conspirators ya him out of the room. As he’s being dragged across the cha Mary rushes forward--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No... But one of the Conspirators holds a pistol up to her, coc at her belly, where her unborn child lies. Then she hears a moan. Looks over to see the melee by the main door. Conspirators stabbing Rizzio relentlessly. The Conspirators step aside, revealing a bloodied Rizzio the ground, his near lifeless eyes still open, labored breaths coming from his riddled chest. He looks to Mary. wants to go to him, but still has the pistol pointed at h

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: (to Darnley) You must make the final blow. Darnley is overcome with fear himself, and sickened by th bloody body before him. But he manages to pull out his da and take a few steps toward Rizzio before stopping.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: Go on.  75.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: I can’t... Lennox has no more patience for his son’s timidity. He gr Darnley by the wrist and drags him over to Rizzio, then drives Darnley’s knife-laden hand into Rizzio to deal the final blow. Darnley lets go of the dagger, horrified. It remains in Rizzio’s chest. On Mary now, breaks into sobs as she sinks to her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bothwell gallops away from Edinburgh - alone on his horse accompaniment - fleeing for his life. He glances back as rides, making sure he’s not being followed. INT. HOLYROOD - QUEEN’S CHAMBERS - DAY Silence except for a swishing sound... Mary and Darnley sit on opposite sides of the room, still both in shock. Mary’s tears are gone, but her eyes are st red, and she’s made still by an oppressive numbness. We CUT TO the source of the swishing sound. Kate is scrub the floor where Rizzio’s corpse was. A Guard is standing her, keeping his eyes on Mary. Kate finishes. Wipes her brow, and exits with the scrub b and bucket. Back on Darnley, who glances over at Mary. She seems to b staring beyond the walls into a bleak and uncertain futur

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: He beguiled us both, Mary. He brought us both dishonour.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You are trying to usurp my crown. Maitland, hearing the hot exchange from the adjacent cham looks inside to see what’s happening.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: (to Mary, pointing) Have I not brought you a child? As much for Maitland’s benefit as Darnley’s--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: One minute makes not a man. Nor do your stupors, which made you more woman than a man.  76. This stings Darnley to the core. He stands, mustering all authority he can.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Beg forgiveness. For your insult.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I shall not. During which an Attendant enters, whispers to Maitland. Maitland turns to Darnley.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: (approaching Darnley) Bothwell has escaped. Darnley turns to him, processing. Mary takes note. Darnle turns back to Mary, his fury rising--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: This is your fault. This chaos. You swore obedience to me on the day of our marriage.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You are a traitor. (to Maitland) As are you. (back to Darnley) And until I am killed, and forever after, God will see you as such.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: You will not be killed, Madam. (to Darnley) Let us go. We have much business. Lord Moray will arrive soon.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My brother conspired...?

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Your brother returns to assist your husband. It’s a blow for Mary - the depth of the treachery.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: I want a drink. Where is the... He looks around for a bottle of something. Heads into the small dining closet. So as not to be heard--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Maitland) Am I to be imprisoned here alone? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or may I have the company of my gentlewomen?

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: You may not, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then at least let my husband remain. Or would you have a drunkard for a King? A beat. Then Maitland exits, closing the door behind hims Upon hearing the door close, Darnley re-enters the main bedroom. Seeing Maitland gone--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come Henry. I do not feel well. She gets up from the chair, then sways, seeming off-balan Darnley heads over to lend her an arm.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you forgive my harsh words?

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: If you will forgive mine.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Help me into bed... She takes his arm as they head to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moray enters the gate on horseback flanked by two armed GUARDS. Maitland hurriedly approaches as he dismounts. Th exchange a few words. Moray walks with brisk urgency towa the entrance, Maitland close behind. INT. HOLYROOD - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - DAY Moray and Maitland enter to find Mary on the bed, clutchi her stomach, moaning in pain. Darnley is beside her, with four Marys and Kate.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: She feigns. Mary looks over at Moray - surprised to see him...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Brother...  78.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: We will need to undress her.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Come. All of you. She is fine.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: If we do not attend to her now, we may lose the child.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: (to Darnley) She feigns.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Moray) Please... Mary grips Darnley’s arm, gritting her teeth in pain.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is your son.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: (to Kate and Seton) Do what you must. (to Moray) Out.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Sir...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Out I say. Moray reluctantly exits.

dialogues.speaker: SETON
dialogues.text: (to Darnley) Your grace...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Yes...of course... And Darnley exits too. As soon as the door is shut, Mary up, completely fine. Moray was right. She feigned. In whispers to the women--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Who else have they killed?

dialogues.speaker: BEATON
dialogues.text: No one. Lord Bothwell has fled.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: (distraught) Madam - had I known...  79.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It is done.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: He said nothing and I am sick with hate. I shall never forgive him or have anything to do with him again.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Compose yourself. We must be strong now. Fleming nods. Mary gets up and retrieves a gold, jewel- encrusted cross from her personal altar. Heads to the des and retrieves a letter opener.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Fleming) Let them hear me. As I was. Fleming begins to moan as Mary was. Meanwhile Mary starts pry the sapphire loose with the opener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seton scurries across the courtyard and approaches the Gu standing sentry at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND MAN 1
dialogues.text: You may not pass, Madam. Seton removes a sealed parchment from the folds of her dr and holds it out for the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: SETON
dialogues.text: Lord Bothwell. Seton slips her fingers into her pocket and pulls out the sapphire from the cross. Places it in the Guard’s hand. H marvels at it. Seton then gives him the letter.  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Darnley in bed. She is in her night clothes now, looking spent. Darnley still has his arms wrapped around They talk quietly, with their eyes closed, like lovers.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not yet. He grips her tighter, pulling her close. He runs a palm across her belly. A pause. Then--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: They forced me to. I didn’t know - not until they arrived. And I was drunk. I believed them. I knew not what I did... She knows it’s an utter lie, but she offers compassion--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Maitland is very persuasive.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My brother even more so. You must be careful of them both. A beat as she lets this settle in, Then--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They will take your crown as well as mine. She lets this sink in for him. Then--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We should leave here. Darnley doesn’t answer. Mary presses, gingerly.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s best. For all three of us. She places her hand on the one he has on her belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnley with Maitland, Moray and Lennox.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Not before she signs the pardons.  81.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: We are drawing up the papers now.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: We will not wait on secretaries.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: It’s important that the people do not accuse those who participated as traitors. They must be pardoned so there is no doubt of their loyalty to the crown.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: When she signs, then you may go.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Am I to be told what I may and may not do? (defiant) Who are these that give me orders? (to Maitland) A mere Lord? (to Moray) A bastard half-brother? (to them both) Am I not the King to whom you promised fealty before you carried out your violence? This King shall go where he pleases with his wife when it pleases him. Bring the papers to us at Linlithgow. And do not mistake your place again. And Darnley exits. Moray and Maitland exchange an exasper glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Council is assembled. Among them Cecil and Dudley. Silence. They wait patiently for Elizabeth. It feels as though they have been there for a long while. Eventually Dudley stands up--  82. INT. HAMPTON COURT - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - DAY Two Ladies hold up Elizabeth's finished quilling design. Elizabeth examines it, Bess at her side. Elizabeth is not pleased with it. She points to a corner where we see an interplay of leaves and flowers.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The flowers are all of one colour.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Poppies are red. I know of no other colour that they--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: In the light they are many colours. Red and others. Nature is more subtle...and confusing... From Bess’s expression we can tell she has no idea what Elizabeth is talking about. A knock. They all turn. The door opens, revealing Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: The council is met. News from Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What do you think? She points to the quilling.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Are the flowers not too plain?

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: The news is urgent...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (to Dudley, fierce) What news do I want from Scotland? Bloodshed? Go conspire among yourselves. Dudley is surprised and shaken by the outburst, but he kn Elizabeth well enough not to press her.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: Very well. He exits. Elizabeth turns back to Bess and her Ladies, wh are as surprised as Dudley was. Regarding the quilling--  83.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Burn it. I shall begin again. The Ladies stand motionless. Not sure if she means it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Burn it I say. They take the quilling to the fireplace and lay it within flames. TIGHT on the carefully constructed flowers charri and uncurling from the heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Darnley and their small entourage approach the cast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Darnley enter. We see scores of soldiers. Darnle was not expecting this and we can read it on his face. As two enter, a command is given and the soldiers all turn t stand at attention. Darnley sees Bothwell, fully armored. Turns to Mary...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: (to Mary) Was this you...? By now Bothwell has approached with two Guards.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: (to Darnley) Your chambers are ready. Darnley looks back at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do not make them use force. Darnley’s shocked by the betrayal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moray, Maitland, Knox and Lennox are met.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: They have at least five hundred. More are on the way.

dialogues.speaker: LENNOX
dialogues.text: Then we shall raise our own army.  84.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: (fatigued) There is no appetite for war.

dialogues.speaker: KNOX
dialogues.text: So let us stir an appetite.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: When last we raised an army it was still but half of hers with England’ will be Moray’s pessimism She has parlay. s help. Without England we crushed. surprises them all. MORAY (CONT’D) outmanoeuvred us. Now we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moray and Maitland are being escorted down the hall to th Receiving Room by Bothwell and several Guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very pregnant Mary looks over a document. Bothwell to t side. Maitland and Moray glance at each other anxiously a she finishes reading, looks up--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My husband claims he knew nothing of your plot until the day itself.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: That is not true. He signed a bond. With his own hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: If you wish it destroyed, however...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not destroyed. (holds up the document) We shall sign this pardon as soon as you produce the bond. Maitland looks to Moray. Moray nods. This can be done.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Aye, Madam.  85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Moray walk side by side. There are SOLDIERS camp outside the palace.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You visited mother and me here, before we left for France. Do you remember?

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Yes. Those were...tumultuous times...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Here, in this field - you lifted me high when I said I wished to be a bird.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: (awkward chuckle) If you say so...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I understand why you wouldn’t remember a trifling thing like that. Of what consequence are the fancies of a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Not all little girls are born to be Queens.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I should like you to hold my child up one day, and make him fly as you made me. She looks to him. He isn’t sure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He will be born a Prince. And one day King. I want him to love his uncle and to be born into a peaceful land.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: I wish the same.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then will you love your sister as you would love her child? He does not answer.  86.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For she still loves you, and if it is a son, she will call him James, for both his grandfather and his uncle. Moray turns, overcome with emotion - a rare event for him Mary touches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: James... He turns back to her, swallowing his tears, clenching his to prevent himself from weeping.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: I do not deserve your kindness. She is as moved hearing it, as he is saying it. She takes hand and kisses it.  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WRITING THE LETTER HERSELF Mary rides in the back of a covered wagon with the Four Marys, too pregnant to ride o her own. A few soldiers accompany the wagon. She looks ou onto landscape, taking in the stark beauty of her Kingdom She seems secure - sure of herself - far more so than whe she first arrived in Scotland. During which--  88.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My dearest cousin - we have had our differences and what sorrow it has brought my heart. But before I bring a child into this world... INT. HAMPTON COURT - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - DAY TIGHT on a flat blade quilling a strip of paper for a hal finished flower. Unlike before, the flowers are a blend o several coloured papers, giving them a shaded look--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...I wish to reconcile. I would our child have two mothers... The hand with the blade suddenly pauses at this, frozen h curl.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ++.a mother who bears him... We PULL BACK to see it is Elizabeth, listening as Bess re the letter to her - although it is still Mary’s voice we hear.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .»+-and you, his chosen Godmother... Elizabeth is visibly moved by this. She sets the blade do

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No child would be more blessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary squats as she is in labor, as children were birthed her time. Her hair is matted with sweat, her face flushed from pain. Kate and the Four Marys are at her side.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I am told the labor was long, but only with suffering do we know joy. What greater joy than to have ...a son to call your own. Humbly do I accept your invitation to be his Godmother, that I might share in your happiness... As the bloody infant James is brought forth with one fina painful push from Mary--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-What is more, we should return the issue of inheritance now that a new generation is upon us...  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James - wiped clean, fast asleep - is being swaddled.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your terms are most agreeable, and delight us greatly. It is only right that your heirs succeed you if you marry... The exhausted but smiling Mary on her bed as the swaddled baby is placed into her arms for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--and bear children of your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth rides in a circle around the corral, holding th reins of a second horse - the foal (now a pony) - trainin to be comfortable with a bridle.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--And should you not, it is my son’s great honor to rule by your sublime example. TIME CUT TO Elizabeth helping to remove the bridle and th petting the horse for having done well.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We must meet him soon, that we might kiss him and show him our love. And so that both his mothers might meet, who for too long have not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is seated in the corner, breast-feeding her infant, warm, glowing maternal smile on her face as she looks dow the suckling child. The Four Marys are present. A knock at the door. Fleming heads to answer the door as Seton retrieves a linen shawl to cover Mary’s breast as t child continues to feed. Once covered, Mary nods to Fleming, who opens the door, revealing Darnley and Bothwell. Darnley looks meek, and t worse for wear.  89A.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: (re the child) May I...?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Come. Darnley goes over. Bothwell averts his eyes so as not to the Queen in undress. Darnley looks down on the child. Attempts to stroke his cheek. But as soon as he does, the child begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shhhh. But the child keeps crying. Beaton comes over. Mary hands child off to her. Beaton rocks the child back and forth a Mary pulls the shawl over herself.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: (a weak smile) Strong lungs. Mary, calm and direct--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We have procured a house for you. Bothwell will see you there. A beat - Darnley comprehends the implication of her words

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: You imprison me? Mary points to a document on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is this not your name? Darnley goes over to it. Looks down. He’s caught, momenta frozen. But the inveterate liar that he is, he retorts wi

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: It is forged.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Henry...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: I swear.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It is your hand.  89B.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: They must have - they must have plied me with wine. They tricked me into it. Those scheming devils...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Stop...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Or that heretic Knox - possessed me with some demon that took hold of my spirit...

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: He is mad...

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: (lashing out at Bothwell) Am I? Am I mad? Yes then, I am mad. (to Mary) For I would never with my own free will-- As he approaches her, desperate--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-You must believe me. But Bothwell steps in between and grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let go, you brute. But Bothwell does not. He looks to Mary again, almost childlike--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please...Am I not to see my own son? Is he not to know his father...?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (calmly) For your child’s sake, be contented with a pardon and your life. (glances at the child) You may say good-bye. Beaton brings the child over to Darnley. Darnley tries to touch the child’s face again, but it only wails louder. T possibility that this may be the last time he ever sees J gets to Darnley. He begins to weep. To Mary--

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: Forgive me...for the love of God...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Go now.  89C.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY
dialogues.text: My darling... She takes the child from Beaton. As she begins to rock hi he stops crying.

dialogues.speaker: DARNLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I beg you...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Bothwell) Take him. Bothwell approaches Darnley and takes his arm. But he won be man-handled again. He wrests his arm away, and with th last bit of dignity he can muster, he exits on his own, Bothwell following. On Mary - rocking the child in her arms as she watches Darnley and Bothwell exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary’s assembled Council - including Moray, Maitland and Bothwell - stand when she enters. TIME CUT to everyone seating, mid-conversation--

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: You must divorce him, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It is forbidden.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Not by the Church of Scotland.  90.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He is the father of my child. I will not do him such an indignity.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: He threatens flight to England. Should he raise an army there--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Elizabeth would not welcome him. She is not so foolish as to choose a degenerate over her sister. INT. ELIZABETH’S COUNCIL - DAY Elizabeth’s council similarly gathered.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: If you grant her succession then we are rewarding her disobedience.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What disobedience? She is not our subject.

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: And yet you would make us hers.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (with heat) What have you produced in all your travels between our kingdoms? Discord. War. Death. And now you have the boldness to doubt my judgment? You had better question yours. Randolph, chin high, trying to maintain as much dignity a possible--

dialogues.speaker: RANDOLPH
dialogues.text: I regret that you perceive me as a failure.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: (stepping in) We serve you fully, with all our hearts. Any one of us would gladly die for you. But Mary is our foe, and a Catholic. Is it not within our rights to ask that we never bow to her as we bow before you?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: She is only your Queen if I should not produce an heir.  90A.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: And will you, Madam? For you have given us little hope so far.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Darnley is cursed. We who have wronged you on his behalf seek only to prevent more wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He is harmless.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Not so. When I delivered him to his lodgings he screamed things most profane, and spoke of regicide.  91.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You have commanded armies against armies. Now you fear a single man?

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: I did not claim to fear him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then why advocate divorce?

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: My oath is to defend your safety.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So you do fear him.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: No, I...what I meant... Bothwell grasps for words. Rhetoric is not a strength.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Just as you vowed to protect me, I vowed loyalty to my husband - however regrettable that vow may be. I owe him neither comfort nor title, but I will not become a lady Henry Eighth, dispensing with husbands as he did wives. INT. ELIZABETH’S COUNCIL -DAY

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Despite your every effort she has prevailed. She has proven herself, in fact, far more capable than my own Privy Council. (sardonically) Should I die before my time, we could do worse than to place her on the throne of England.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: ...I have brought peace to our land, produced an heir to my throne and arranged succession to my sister’s. Our strength is secure. Her command of the room is total. Then, with a softer ton

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let my husband rave and threaten. We pity his madness, and it is punishment enough.  92. As Mary stands, the Lords begin to stand and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobles are exiting the Receiving Hall. Maitland and other are in a small conspiratorial group. As Moray passes-—

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Sir, join us... He ignores them and keeps walking. Maitland is surprised. Bothwell emerges. Maitland turns his attention to Bothwel

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My Lord, you argued well in Council. May we borrow your wisdom for a moment? Bothwell is sceptical but intrigued. The circle opens to INT. HOLYROOD - QUEEN’S BEDCHAMBER —- EVENING THREE YEAR OLD JAMES sees something in the ashes of the fireplace and teeters towards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hooded men place the barrels in the center of the cel their work lit by a single lantern. One of them opens one the barrels and scoops a pile of dark powder into his han Begins to lay a trail of the powder back toward the door. INT. DARNLEY’S HOUSE - CELLAR - NIGHT At the cellar’s entrance one of the hooded figures lowers candle and lights the trail of powder. It begins to burn towards the barrel as the men hastily exit.  93. INT. HOLYROOD - QUEEN’S BEDCHAMBER —- EVENING THREE YEAR OLD JAMES plays in the ashes of the fireplace. INT. DARNLEY’S HOUSE - SITTING ROOM - NIGHT A half-dressed Darnley and a naked YOUNG MAN seated at a table, both drunk. They reach for the bottle at the same time, knocking the bottle off the table and breaking a gl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES finds a DEAD BIRD in the ashes of the fire grate an reaches towards it. INT. DARNLEY’S HOUSE - SITTING ROOM - NIGHT Darnley tries to pick up the glass but cuts himself in th process. Winces in pain. Looks for a piece of cloth to wr his finger in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary hurries over to James and lifts him up and away from carrion. Rubs his hands clean with the hem of her dress. INT. DARNLEY’S HOUSE - SITTING ROOM - NIGHT Darnley is wrapping his finger with his shirt tail, tryin stem the blood he bends down to pick up the bottle when-- BOOM with a FLASH that fills the screen, an explosion roc the room. Darnley and the naked YOUNG MAN is hit by the b of the explosion. A tapestry is blown from the wall acros the room, onto Darnley bending over on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary bolts up in bed, awakened from the sound. The Four M are stirred awake too. James is standing in his crib, cry

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. DARNLEY'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: FLAMES whooshing from the blown out window, engulfing the house.  93A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DARNLEY splutters awake in the burning building. He grabs tapestry and, using it to cover himself, runs from the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO the Hooded figures, watching this from afar. CUT TO their POV and we see Darnley, stumbling from the house. Wrapped in the smoking tapestry. CUT TO the Hooded Men walking briskly toward him. One of the Hooded Men bends down and, using the cord of t smoking tapestry throttles Darnley. His eyes bulge in fea the life is choked out of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is sitting at one of the tables, cradling James, who fast asleep. The Four Marys are with her. There are half dozen Guards in the room. Bothwell enters. He sits down across from her. Gently--  94.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: It was Lord Darnley. Off Mary’s puzzled look-- BOTHWELL (CONT’D) An attempt on his life.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is he dead? Bothwell gives her a sympathetic look which confirms this Mary breaks into sobs. James wakes up, troubled by his mother’s tears. Seton comes over and takes the child from her, who has begun to cry himself.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: I'll bring you to my estates. It’s not safe for you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky gray with pre-dawn light. Mary’s final few trunks being loaded onto a wagon. Mary is kneeling before James, holding his hands to help him stand. Seton awaits on a ho Bothwell is with them. She’s saying good-bye, and it’s ha

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Will you be good? The child stares blankly at her. She lifts the child up to Seton. The child looks as thoug might cry. Mary takes his foot and shakes it. His would-b tears morph into giggles.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes - you’ll be good. And she tenderly kisses his foot. Then nods to Seton, try to remain strong in her farewell. Seton begins to trot ou the gate, accompanied by two SOLDIERS on horseback. Mary watches them go for a moment, in an impenetrable daz lost in her thoughts, oblivious to all else. Bothwell pla a hand on her shoulder. Then leads her toward her own hor and the wagon where the three other Marys are already sea cloaks on, ready for the journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Bothwell and the Royal Entourage approach the castl a gloomy, militaristic seaside edifice.  95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is being undressed by her ladies. They have only rem her outer sleeves when the door opens, revealing Bothwell turns away so as not to see her unsleeved arms.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Pardon... The ladies move to re-attach her sleeves but Mary decline

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No need.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: May we speak in private? She nods to the Marys. They file out past Bothwell, still turned from her as he shuts the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You may look. ‘Tis only my arms. He turns to her. He looks nervous. It’s unlike him.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: I know it is smaller than your lodgings in Edinburgh, but I hope it will suffice.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What brings you? Bothwell hesitates, then finding his confidence, launches

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: The Parliament will ratify a proclamation demanding you wed a Scottish subject now that you are widowed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It has only been a day...

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: They meet tomorrow. It is your council’s advice that you should marry me. And now she’s beginning to connect the dots--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My God...What have you done? Bothwell simply stares at her.  96.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Madam...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Leave me. Now.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Madam...calm yourself... He moves toward her. She skirts around him and heads for door, but he grabs her by the wrist. He pushes her onto t bed and holds her down.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Murderer.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Did I not come to your aid when your Lords rebelled? Mary resists. BOTHWELL (CONT’D) Refuse and I will not come to your aid when they rebel again.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Please... He lets go. She sits up, overcome with sobs. Bothwell goe the door and opens it. To the three Marys in the hall--

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Come. They enter, bewildered and concerned to see Mary in tears BOTHWELL (CONT’D) Undress your lady. They look to Mary. She is wiping her tears away now.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO--
dialogues.text: Bothwell grunting over her. Perfunctory. Mary expressionl trying to block out what is happening. A POP to the three Marys outside the draped bed, fighting back their own tears as they hear Bothwell within, forcin himself upon their mistress.  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knox stands before his congregation as we saw him earlier the film. But now the room is doubly packed, people spill outside and lining the walls. And far more COMMONERS than saw the first time. Knox is really worked up.

dialogues.speaker: KNOX
dialogues.text: The Queen is servant of Satan. She is a fornicator. A whore of Bablyon who defies the sanctity of marriage. What’s worse, she has broken the most solemn of commandments: Thou Shalt Not Kill... We CUT TO the face of the commoners, rapt by the sermon, bubbling anger in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: KNOX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She had her husband killed so she could wed his rival. Would we worship a murderous harlot? Would we kneel before a polecat who bedded an Italian? An agent of Rome? David Rizzio was slain for such adultery, and now Queen Strumpet marries another man whom she bedded out of wedlock. How do we know her son is not a bastard? Our Kingdom has become a disgrace - to God and all the world...

dialogues.speaker: COMMONER
dialogues.text: (yelling out) Death to the whore! The crowd, whipped into a fervor, yells in approval. Othe start chanting “Death to the whore!” We hear their yells chants continue as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Bothwell at the altar of the chapel, the Bishop presiding. Maitland and Moray are in attendance. TIME CUT TO Bothwell placing the rings on Mary’s hand. Th kneel and the Bishop blesses them both, then begins to pr This may be INTERCUT with the scene 154, adding a layer o the priests chanting in the wedding portion.  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATE scrubs graffiti off the walls of Holyrood. INT. HAMPTON COURT - QUEEN’S CHAMBER - NIGHT Elizabeth and Dudley on her bed, the drapes drawn for privacy. They are clothed. Her head is in his lap as he strokes her hair. It’s very quiet and intimate.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Are we to do nothing as my sister is deposed?

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: She is not your sister. Nor can she be your successor. Not a woman whose own subjects call her a harlot.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: This is Cecil speaking...

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: I speak for myself. Though all your council agrees.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (more to herself than him) How cruel men are.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY
dialogues.text: What was that? She does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maitland and Moray sit across a table from Mary and Bothw There is no food. Only the bare table top and the solemni of the conversation. Moray hates every moment of this. Bothwell is furious. To Maitland and Moray.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: You promised that I would be King.  99.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: (coolly) If your betrothed does abdicate, you are abdicated also.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: This was your intention...

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Events have overtaken all intentions.

dialogues.speaker: BOTHWELL
dialogues.text: Liar! Events. Aye. Events by your design. Is that not so? They do not answer. BOTHWELL (CONT’D) Speak...Be men and own your treachery. Did you not deceive me? While Bothwell is shocked, Mary is not. Looking Moray straight in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: As they have done their Queen since the day she returned. Moray, ashamed, looks down at his hands.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Bothwell) Were you fool enough to trust these men? Who took up arms against you? Bothwell looks tortured, having been played.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: You must abdicate, Madam. She turns back to Maitland.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When your son comes of age, he will assume the throne. (nodding to Moray) Until then my Lord will be Regent.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Moray) Brother?

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: We found Mistress Seton. The boy is now in our custody at Holyrood.  99A.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You hold my son prisoner?

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Not prisoner. He is my ward, until he is old enough to--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Your namesake, James. Named for you.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: I beg your forgiveness. (beat) But if you wish him to be King one day, you must abdicate.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I will not do it.  100.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: You will, Madam. By force if we must.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then I shall meet force with force. Maitland has reached the end of his patience.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: The people believe you are a traitor and a whore. What army can defeat an entire nation turned against its Queen? They would sooner parade your head on a pike than bow before a harlot. I for one would gladly hold high the pike. Mary is shocked by his blood-lust. Looks to Moray--

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: (matter-of-factly) He is right. You cannot raise an army.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (defiant) Many times you have said I cannot do what I have done.

dialogues.speaker: MAITLAND
dialogues.text: Then we are finished here. Maitland gets up and heads for the door. Moray remains seated. Maitland turns back, waiting for him. Moray, with true supplication, not wanting further conflict--

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: This is beyond my control. I ask you to reconsider.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: All I have done is try to unify this land. A glimmer of hope on Moray’s face. Is she bending? But Ma only allows her self-doubt to linger for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To relinquish the crown would be against God’s will.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: God will not protect you. But I will protect you as my kin. More lamentable than defiant--  101.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I wish that we were kin. But we are no longer so. Moray nods, disappointed. He understands and cannot fault her. He stands and makes his way towards the door. Bothwell moves his hand on top of Mary’s. She pulls hers away. She cannot be comforted, certainly not by him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is with the three remaining Marys at the cliff’s edg overlooking the ocean. She and Fleming are at the fore, Livingston and Beaton several yards behind. The waves are crashing below. In French--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Si vous souhaitez fuir, vous et les autres, vous devriez le faire immédiatement. (If you and the others wish to flee, you should do so.)

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Notre obligation est a vous. Nous n’en avons pas 4 nous-mémes. (Our duty is to you, not ourselves.)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Vous avez assez fait. Vous ne me devez pas vos vies. (You have done enough. You do not owe me your lives.)

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Vous ne devriez pas non plus risquer la vétre. (Nor should you risk yours.)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Je n’ai pas le choix. (I have no choice.)

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Mais certes vous avez le choix. (Of course you do.) (gesturing to the ocean) Regardez. La France est si proche, nous pourrions presque la toucher. (France is so close we could almost touch it.)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (glancing back) Prenez Livingston avec vous. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Elle s’est toujours sentie dépaysée ici. Et Beaton languirait si elle se trouvait toute seule. (Take Livingston. She has never felt at home here. And Beaton would not fare well on her own.)

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Mais Madame ... (But Madam..

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Faites ce que je vous dis. (Do as I say.)

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Les soeurs de se délaissent pas. (Sisters do not abandon sisters.)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Une reine n’a pas de soeurs. Elle n’a que son pays. (A Queen has no sisters. She has only her country.)

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Un pays qui vous a délaissée. (Which has turned on you.) And now Fleming gestures to the land instead of the ocean

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Vous risquez tout pour ce pays maudit et execrable? (You would risk everything for this wretched land and its wretched people?)
