dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I would.

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Le jeu n’en vaut pas la chandelle. (It is not worth it.)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Je ne m’attends pas 4 votre compréhension. Il n’y a qu’une autre reine qui puisse comprendre. (I do not expect you to understand. Only another Queen could.)

dialogues.speaker: FLEMING
dialogues.text: Elle vous a pourtant délaissée, elle aussi. (She too has turned on you.)  103.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Et elle pourrait faire pire encore. Mais je ne vais pas m’enfuir. (And may do worse yet. But I will not flee her.) Now Mary turns her back on the sea to gaze on the land--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma vie est ici maintenant. (My life is here now.) We begin to hear the sound of BAGPIPES--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James - five years old now - is running forward, much mor able on his feet than when we saw him last. He’s darting toward something he sees on the cobblestones. Seton is following him at a leisurely pace several yards behind. James arrives at his destination and crouches down - it’s musket ball wedged between two cobblestones. He picks it and stares at it, fascinated. He starts to lick the muske ball. Seton scurries forward.

dialogues.speaker: SETON
dialogues.text: No. She takes the musket ball out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Francais?

dialogues.speaker: SETON
dialogues.text: Balle. He sees another one. Runs over and picks it up. Then anot Picks that one up too. Seton follows. As he rounds the corner he sees a PLATOON of troops mustering. A QUARTERMASTER is handing out musket balls to troops from a bucket, which they are placing in pouches. PIPER plays during all of this. Seton comes up alongside James, who is staring at the tro with as much fascination as he did the musket ball.

dialogues.speaker: SETON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Soldat.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Soldat.

dialogues.speaker: SETON
dialogues.text: Soldiers.  104.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What is soldiers?

dialogues.speaker: SETON
dialogues.text: They fight.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Fight what?

dialogues.speaker: SETON
dialogues.text: (with some sadness) Ta mere. James looks up at Seton, not fully understanding. PRELAP: the SOUND of a MASSIVE BATTLE - screams, yells, t clanking and clashing of arms, then CUT TO--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KNOX stands before congregation. We see images of Mary an Moray preparing for battle.

dialogues.speaker: KNOX
dialogues.text: Oh Lord, hear our prayer, that we may rid this land of this Harlot- Queen and her murderer-husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARY alone at prayer. Bothwell, unnoticed is behind her. watches her and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MORAY at prayer with his soldiers on the eve of battle. I a huge and well-armed force.

dialogues.speaker: KNOX V.O
dialogues.text: Hear our prayer for those men, who do as God commands them to do... .-».not that which seems good in their own eyes. YOUNG JAMES I has crept into the church and is watching M through the soldiers’ legs.

dialogues.speaker: KNOX V.O
dialogues.text: Our prayers will be heard. But those Catholic traitors who fight with her, speak into the void.  104A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERY TIGHT on HECTOR - THE HIGHLANDER - the one who Mary spoke to. His entire face fills the screen. We see nothin else. It is streaked with mud and caked blood. He is on h back. Fallen. We can hear the battle surrounding him on all sides, CLAMORING and FIERCE, but see NOTHING of it, only his fac He gurgles fresh blood from his mouth. The sound of the battle starts to FADE as we push into his eyes, replaced by the sound of his strained breathing. As we push CLOSER we hear his voice, in SCOTTISH GAELIC, struggling to recite “Hail Mary”--

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Failte dhut a Mhoire, tha thu lan de na grasan... We CUT TO his POV - straight up. Nothing but the sky fill the frame--

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tha an Tighearna maille riut. Is beannaichte thu am measg nam mna... CUT TO VERY TIGHT on MARY'S EYES - filled with horror - watching the battle from afar. Only her EYES fill the fra slowly pulling out to see the despair on her face--

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: «--agus beannaichte toradh do bhronn, Iosa. A Naoimh Mhoire, Mhathair Dhé, guidh air ar son ne na peacaich...  105. CUT BACK TO the SKY, as it fades to BLACK-- .--a nis, agus aig uair ar bais. And just before it reaches total black, we hear hear the last, shallow breath of the Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CONTINUATION of Scene 161. On James looking at the gate Moray enters on horseback, flanked by two CALVARYMEN also horseback. He is muddy from the battle. Sees the troops mustering. All activity stops and they stand at attention he slowly rides in. To a CAPTAIN overseeing the Quarterma

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: Dismiss them. The Captain stares at him blankly. In anger, mixed with h own shame and fatigue-- MORAY (CONT’D) Dismiss them! It is done. There’s nothing euphoric about this victory. The Captain immediately forms the troops to march out of the courtyar During which Moray sees James and Seton. He dismounts and approaches the child as he takes his gloves off. Seton lo concerned.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (in French) Where is maman? He crouches down to eye-level with James. Places his hand over the child’s heart.

dialogues.speaker: MORAY
dialogues.text: She is here. (beat) And you will make her proud... Then he lifts the child up - and holding him so he’s now the eye-level of a grown man-- MORAY (CONT’D) .--for one day you will be King. And all this will be yours.

dialogues.speaker: SETON
dialogues.text: (to Moray) Does she live?  106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pre-dawn light. The FISHERMAN preparing a rowboat for the journey across. Two of Mary’s ESCORTS are with her. As th Fisherman sets to unfurling the sail, Mary gazes out acro the water at a thin ribbon of land on the horizon--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: England does not look so different from Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Aye, they are sisters. She stares into the distance a moment longer, then heads to the rowboat. The Fisherman and the Escorts help her bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Elizabeth, trying on a wig - bright red. Looking into a hand mirror that Bess is holding up for her.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Let us try the other. One of her Ladies removes the current wig as Bess retriev the second one and helps Elizabeth put it on. Then holds mirror up to her again. Elizabeth takes the mirror hersel she can see it from all angles.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Madam. Elizabeth tilts the mirror and in it sees Cecil in the doorway. As Cecil steps into the room so he can face her-

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If anyone were to learn of such a meeting - whether it be the Scottish Lords or our own here in--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I agree that secrecy is vital. Alas, you have a skill for keeping such things hidden. So put your skills to use.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL
dialogues.text: Is it guilt, Madam? Elizabeth turns to him, offended. He has struck a nerve.  107.

dialogues.speaker: CECIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because a monarch should never feel guilt.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (sharply) My motive is not your concern. Do as I say and make the arrangements. Cecil is smart enough not to challenge the rebuke. He bow submission and exits. Elizabeth picks up the mirror and inspects the wig once more.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This one I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small cottage in a clearing surrounded by woods. The Attache is out front, keeping guard. He hears dogs barkin the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is at a small window, looking out.

dialogues.speaker: ATTACHE
dialogues.text: Away from the window, Madam. Mary steps away from the window and the Attache shutters A moment later Bess enters. Eyes Mary for a moment, then turns to the attache.

dialogues.speaker: BESS
dialogues.text: I rode ahead. She’1l be here soon. On Mary, full of anticipation at hearing this. Then Bess whispers something into the attache’s ear. He turns to Ma

dialogues.speaker: ATTACHE
dialogues.text: Come. He leads her to the rear, hidden by washing hanging from rafters, out of sight from the front of the room.

dialogues.speaker: ATTACHE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remain here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAPTAIN helps Elizabeth off her horse. So as to be he by the rest in the hunting party--  107A.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I should like some privacy whilst I rest.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Of course, Madam. Elizabeth makes her way toward the cottage alone.  108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth enters. Looks around the main room and sees Bes and the Attache. He bows.

dialogues.speaker: ATTACHE
dialogues.text: Your Majesty. They silently retreat to another portion of the cottage, leaving Elizabeth alone. She does not move. BACK TO Mary, leaning forward, tempted to get up and meet her, but remaining where she is as instructed. BACK TO Elizabeth, her heart is pounding too. She takes several steps forward. CUT TO Mary as footfalls draw near, floorboards creaking. Then they stop. Mary listens for a moment, still, should she say somethin CUT BACK TO Elizabeth, frozen. She is building the courag confront Mary. BACK TO Mary--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Cousin...? And we INTERCUT between the two, in separate spaces, hear but not seeing each other.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (barely audible) Aye... Elizabeth swallows her anxiety and steadies herself. Loud

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you well? Mary desperately wants to go to her but holds back. She doesn’t want to do anything to offend Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Your voice is not what I expected.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: What did you expect of it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I do not know.  109.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Vous préférez que nous nous parlions en frangais? (Would you rather we speak French?)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We are in your country. I shall speak your language. She waits for Elizabeth to respond, but she does not. Mar takes a step closer.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How I long to see your face. But she stops short of revealing herself.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No one can know we meet.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, I have been instructed.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: If you speak of it to anyone, I shall deny. And I will regard your words as treason.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Am I your subject now?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (softer) No - you are not my subject. (beat) But you seek refuge.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (swallowing pride) I am grateful for your protection. They are so close, but still cannot see each other.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did it come to this? Elizabeth does not have an answer.  110.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I see you, sister? Elizabeth is frozen. Mary waits, but with no response, st into the same space as Elizabeth. As she does Elizabeth turns, so her back is to Mary. Elizabeth brings her finge to the side of her wig, making sure there are no underlay locks out of place.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: My eyes are weary from travel. Mary gazes at Elizabeth’s back.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I should have stayed true to your love. I should have followed your example and never married.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: But then you would have no son.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Whom I have not seen these past two years. Whose mother is without a crown. Whose own throne is usurped by his uncle. Elizabeth still has her back to Mary--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You must have faith your brother will keep his word.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I have no faith in him. (beat) I have only faith in you. On Elizabeth, closing her eyes. She can guess what is to next, and it is a difficult matter. Mary takes a few step closer to her--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You would let them show the world that a Queen can so easily be forsworn? No answer from Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Answer me, sister.  111.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: To war with Scotland and betray my own clergy on a Catholic’s behalf - no. I cannot. You know I cannot.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Did you come so far at such great risk only to refuse me?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I came because... But she decides not to finish the sentence. Mary waits, t

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: If you refuse me, say it to my face. Do not force to me beg to your back. Elizabeth turns and they take each other in for the first time. We see pride and humility on both their faces, ange and love, compassion and antagonism - a kaleidoscope of contradictions. Then, eventually--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will kneel before you if I must.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It would make no difference. You are safe here in England. But that is all I can offer. Mary cannot contain her emotion any longer, her frustrati and anger and sorrow and despair rise up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I have been abandoned by so many. I am utterly alone.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: As am I. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then be my sister. Be my boy’s Godmother. Together we could conquer all of those who doubt us. Do not play into their hands. Our enmity is precisely what they hope for. I know your heart has more within it than the men who counsel you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I am more man than woman now. The throne has made me so. (beat)  112.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I have no enmity with you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Except to seed rebellion and deceive me time and time again.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You would do well to watch your words.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I will not be scolded by my inferior. Elizabeth is stunned by the comment.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Your inferior...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I am a Stuart, which gives me greater claim to England than you possess. Elizabeth brings a hand to her wig--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I had this made because I wanted to present the best version of myself. She takes off the wig and stares at it as--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was jealous. Your beauty. Your bravery. Your motherhood... She looks up at Mary--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You seemed to surpass me in every way. (a beat, then coldly) But now I see there was no cause for envy. Your gifts are your downfall. She tosses the wig onto the dining table. Mary is shaken, tries to maintain her dignity. Chin held high.  113.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What now, sister?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You will still have my protection. On my terms.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Until you have me killed.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I will do no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you? As Henry killed your mother?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I am not my father.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: His blood is your blood.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: As long as you do not provoke my enemies, you have nothing to fear. Your fate is in your own hands.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: If I seek to help your enemies, tis only because you pushed me to their arms. And should you murder me, remember that you murder your sister...and you murder your Queen. That is the final straw. Elizabeth goes to the door leadi to the kitchen and opens it. Both Bess and the Attache st As Elizabeth goes to the door Bess glances over at Mary, glares back at her, defiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Elizabeth approaches the hunting party, she forces a s for show. Everyone starts to mount their horses. Elizabet in hushed tones to the CAPTAIN as he lifts her to her sad

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Take her somewhere you can guard her well.  114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT on a hand reaching into a small bucket of musket ba grabbing one and placing it into another’s hand. We PULL to see it has been given by a SCOTTISH COLONEL to a YOUNG MAN, only 20-years old. The Young Man places the ball int the barrel of the musket, then pushes it down with a rod. He lifts the musket to his shoulder and takes aim at a st target placed on the other side of the courtyard. Pulls t trigger and fires the weapon, hitting his mark.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Very good.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Another. As the Colonel retrieves another musket ball, an ATTENDAN approaches with a folded parchment.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Sir... The Young Man looks over. ATTENDANT (CONT’D) A letter, from England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, the Young Man reads the letter, the expanse of the valley below. We hear Elizabeth’s voice, much older and deeper now--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My dear cousin, I write to you of your mother, whose care you have entrusted to us these many years... And now we realise that the young man is James. We REPRISE PORTIONS OF THE FOOTAGE from the beginning of film - where we only see Mary from behind - but now with Elizabeth’s letter overlaid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is on her knees in prayer, joined by her CHAMBERMAIDS facing the door.  115.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: With an extreme dolor that overwhelms my mind for that miserable incident which has befallen... The heavy door pivots open, revealing Andrews. He bows hi head, then, with solemnity and respect--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREWS
dialogues.text: It’s time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth walks toward us, looking the age we saw her las

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I tell you that while I mourn, I feel no guilt, for I am innocent... Elizabeth rounds the corner and we see her appear on the other side, she is 10 years older - more make-up, a brigh wig, her dress more regal--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...A Prince cannot be guilty for what is just. What other answer to such plots against my throne... A double set of doors are opened for her and as we see he pass through she is another 5 years older, more gaunt, he dress even more elaborate and severe--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...than to respond to treason with the punishment that it demands. How it ages me to bear such a burden... Another set of double doors. And this time as she passes through we see her finally at age 54, the year of Mary’s execution. She almost looks inhuman - thick make up hidin wrinkles, a fiery wig, massive collar and ornate dress. S has entered the Privy Council Chamber---

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...the figurehead of justice that would take away a mother you remember not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On James, tears welling in his eyes as he looks out over valley...  116.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-Know that when I see her in my mind’s eye, I see not an aged woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As an aged Cecil places a document before Elizabeth - the warrant for Mary’s execution - she stares directly at us, stoic, an old woman lost in a memory--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...but rather the young, resplendent Queen whose portrait I first gazed upon five and twenty years ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary approaches the Great Hall as she did at the beginnin but now we are in front of her instead of behind her, and is the young, resplendent Queen Elizabeth imagines--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No older than when she first set foot upon this island...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vast room is filled with a hundred spectators. The wo stage. Soldiers to the side. The crowd parts to make room for Mary and her procession they enter. The spectators look upon her with silent awe fascination as she heads directly for the stage, mounts t steps to the platform where two MASKED MEN stand waiting her. One of them offers her a small stool on which to sit

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO--
dialogues.text: TIGHT on Mary as The Clerk of Elizabeth’s Privy Council, ROBERT BEALE - reads the warrant--

dialogues.speaker: BEALE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: By order of our sovereign Elizabeth, Queen of England, Wales Ireland and Overlord of Scotland, certified... He continues on after the word “Scotland” but his voice f out as Mary begins to speak, directly to the camera, in a quiet, intimate voice.  117.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: James, my only son, I pray that with your life you will succeed where I could not, and for which I am about to give my life... We CUT TO Bull - the Executioner - who bows his head in supplication--

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: I plead your forgiveness, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I forgive you with all my heart. For now, I hope, you shall make an end of all my troubles. Bull gestures to a cushion before her in front of the blo Mary kneels and begins to pray, head bowed, eyes closed--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Salve, Regina, Mater misericordie, vita, dulcedo, et spes nostra, salve. Ad te clamamus exsules filii Heve, In te Domino confido... Her Latin prayer fades as it is replaced my Mary's V.O.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I shall be watching you from heaven... Mary’s eyes open as Bull places his hand on Mary’s should We hear the steady drone of a single bag pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, in full regal attire, sitting on Elizabeth’s thron crown atop his head, scepter in hand, staring straight in the camera--

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As your crown, one day, unites two Kingdoms. A flourish of notes from the bag pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bull gently guides her head to the chopping block. We are TIGHT on her face as we see the frescoed ceiling beyond it.  118. She is trying to keep calm but she is breathing fast now, pulse racing in her final few moments. The axe will fall second. To us, in a whisper as the pipes play--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And we shall have peace. A deep intake of air, the pipes growing even louder. A sl exhale. The briefest flash of calm. BLACKOUT. SILENCE.
